Of the 16 piece collection (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/0IZYHvXNCuAr6rcBrA3EfA/l) that I purchased I was able to sample 12 of the candies.  Following is a piece by piece account of what I tried and my opinion of each.

Dark Milk (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Ojhmf9f89KERQMWWIJ4IuQ/l) - Thin dark chocolate shell.  Firm, creamy and smooth dark milk chocolate center.  Delightful!

Fresh Lime (http://static2.px.yelp.com/bphoto/8EXd5zns-GIdNH3hEY1VcA/l) - It's a tasty piece of chocolate, but the lime flavoring just isn't there.  Flavored with fresh lime juice the thick, creamy ganache is wonderfully chocolatey, but offered nothing to please the lime lover in me.

Hazelnut (http://static2.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Wdglf08JuOoaj6vqGKRJjA/l) - The milk chocolate shell was creamy but what I like most was the gritty, slightly crunchy filling of crushed hazelnuts.

Jamaican Rum (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/i_jyzR3NhOldcHa2K1UqtQ/l) - White chocolate shell with a thick dark chocolate ganache flavored with Jamaican rum.  I didn't taste the rum.

Mint (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/4Ac-MENYV4ytQYhW-rbOAw/l) - I consider mint to be one of the most basic flavorings for chocolate, and I was really excited about this one until I bit into it.  This was a huge disappointment with not even enough mint flavoring to leave a cool taste in my mouth.

Passion Fruit (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/eB1HYJJvSFnm926C7nDXeg/l) - The white chocolate shell was somewhat gritty, but the passion fruit laced caramel had good passion fruit flavor to it.

Raspberry (http://static3.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ffmqh_27u3RdWHwcxsDDrg/l) - Thin dark chocolate shell with a dual layered filling of smooth dark chocolate ganache on top and what seemed to be a thin raspberry gelle on the bottom.  The raspberry flavoring wasn't as defined as I would have liked.

Spiced Caramel (http://static2.px.yelp.com/bphoto/rhdCHRyLWkOM2Qr-cfG9Dg/l) - Outstanding center combines a bit of salted caramel mixed with chile and spice.  It's quite unique and very tasty.  The thick dark chocolate shell actually ruined the overall presentation.

Strawberry (http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/blw4WCj6lOpwuuxeOMg8sg/l) - Similar to the Raspberry with a thin dark chocolate shell and a dual layered filling of smooth dark chocolate ganache on top and a strawberry gelle on the bottom.

Strawberry-Balsamic Caramel (http://static2.px.yelp.com/bphoto/BSkedeKLgA7PQQn2VBiQcw/l) - The liquid center had a very good balsamic vinegar taste to it, but the strawberry flavoring was too subtle.  The outer shell is dark chocolate.

Vanilla Bean (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/7hJM0ecOAMQwLdycR_1gWg/l) - Dark milk chocolate outer shell with a liquid caramel center.  The vanilla flavor was there but very lightly.

Yuzu (http://static3.px.yelp.com/bphoto/vX6bQlR1nDFa30gMqF-zVw/l) - The thick, creamy ganache had a nice citrus flavoring that is comparable to the preserved citrus rinds often used in Asian cooking.  I liked this one which paired well with the thin dark chocolate shell.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Exceptionally beautiful, exploding with flavor, reasonably priced, nicely packaged, unique, elegant, exceptional artisanal chocolates, superlatively tasty, a must try. My current favorite treat and gift.
author: Deborah H.

description: I'm a huge sucker for fine chocolate and I've heard about elbow chocolate here and there. I know I had to try it and glad I did because their customer service was awesome and they give free samples! My favorite is the macadamia praline and earl grey tea.
author: Sherry P.

description: The chocolates here are excellent. They are beautiful and finely detailed both in appearance and taste. Yes, you can really taste the infused variety of flavors in the chocolates instead of guessing where it went or what it is, not like some chocolatiers that claim it has a certain ingredient infused, but you can't even tell or taste that ingredient. The staff are friendly and helpful. This is a great place to buy someone a present. A box of fine chocolates is always a winner.  Buy it here and you win.
author: Valerie C.

description:
For my final sweet bite of the Bay I would happen across a location based not in San Francisco, but rather in Kansas City, Missouri - Christopher Elbow Chocolates.  Having read about and seen the American born chef's work at such fine retailers as Dean&Deluca DC, Trotter's to Go Chicago, and Le Chocoholique right here in Columbus but having never decided to indulge previously I decided to stop in to browse and having experienced some of the better chocolates here in the United States as well as in Paris I can say without a doubt that I'm glad I made that decision.

With the store itself rather minimalist - tablets, bars, and cocoa powders on the wall with a case of truffles and chocolates at the room's center - I was greeted by a pair of young ladies while two couples sat in the small Jacques Genin-esque tasting room to the left chatting and enjoying their selections.  With ambient music playing overhead and the store quite serene I took my time making my decisions and while browsing was offered first a piece of the Dark Almond No 7 "61% with ground roasted almonds" bar and then a $2 "Extra Dark - Bittersweet dark chocolate ganache" - both intense, smooth, and with deep floral notes giving praise to the cocoa's Venezuelan roots.

Continuing to browse as a pair of young ladies stopped in to pick up some pate a fruit and chocolates to go I eventually made my decisions - 4 chocolates and a "liquid chocolate" to be enjoyed while I flipped through my e-mail via the store's free wifi.  Beginning first with the chocolates my selections included Tupelo Honey, Bananas Foster, Port Wine and Fig, and Caramel Fleur de Sel - the first two part of the summer seasonal collection and the second pair part of Elbow's signature series - and each was wonderful, a perfect balance of the expected chocolate tones and the high quality ingredients contained within.  Difficult to decide which was my favorite I would lean largely to the boozy selections as the rum and the port both really highlighted the nuances of the chocolate while still allowing the fruits to shine.

Moving on to the "Liquid Chocolate" described as Cocoa Noir 71% with milk (also available with water or as a white chocolate) with a thick spongy marshmallow on the side this $4.75 selection was equal to or better than the outstanding chocolates and with rich bitter notes punctuating the low cocoa tones the flavor reminded me very favorably (again) of Jacques Genin in Paris, though not quite as rich, creamy, and throat coating overall.  Comparable to the dark chocolate hot cocoa at Cambridge stalwart LA Burdick and vastly more dense and nuanced than the raved versions Recchiuti I'd strongly recommend giving it a try because whether native to the area or not San Francisco is lucky to have one of only two Elbow storefronts and the style, service, and quality are every bit worth the price.
author: Michael U.

description:
So my neighbor tells me she splurged today and got a hot cocoa. I was like huh? I didn't even think this place had such a thing. In fact I had never even walked in here in the 3 years living in the neighborhood until she put the thought in my head. Well it turns out their hot cocoa is pretty good. You can mix a few things into it and top it off with a huge marshmallow. Well I was here for chocolate as any sweet loving sweethtooth kid could. I have to say it was good, but really pricey. I think the full box is like 80 bucks. The chocolates are actually pretty well painted, but I am a sucker for the turtles. I mean gooey caramel, peanuts and don't forget chocolate. Damn ok I may sneak a few in every once and while. 

If it's not busy I believe they will give you a sample.
author: Greg G.

description:
The hot dark chocolate drinks will give you sweet chocolate dreams.  

They have such unique flavors. I learned that you can buy the cocoa noir mix and change up the flavors yourself. 

Things you can add: 
-Peanut Butter
-Hazelnut Butter
-Spices 
-Peppermint
-And so much more...

I tried making my own version at home, but it doesn't taste as good. I need Marcus! Marcus is the charming guy behind the counter. Great service really adds to the overall experience. 

Other comments: 

The chocolate here is so pretty and would make great gifts. Sadly, they are not vegan. Vegan items include the pate de fruit, some of dark chocolate bars, and the hot dark chocolate mixes.
author: Tina B.

description: I found the shop to be quite charming, and the employees were both pleasant and knowledgeable about their wares. Having said that, somehow the offerings don't quite seem to justify the entire space to me. All of the chocolates looked pretty interesting, but honestly the ones with the most appeal were the candies - I was very impressed by how much hazelnut and hazelnut butter was used. I'd come back to try the drinking chocolate.
author: Lisa K.

description: This store is a Kansas City chain and the SF location did not disappoint. The chocolate was amazing and the woman working the counter was patient and helpful. Samples always win me over and she was generous with those as well.
author: Julie R.

description:
For being the chocoholic that I am, it's surprising that I hadn't been to this place earlier...it's awesome!

I stopped by here and they had samples of their Vanazuelan Dark, which was fantastic - deep, dark, but smooth ganache covered in delicate dark chocolate.  This was a great way to welcome me to the boutique.  Looking at all the items, it's tough to choose...everything looks so good.  I eventually settled for the Cocoa Noir Drinking Chocolate, which you can enjoy on the premises in their nice and modern lounge...wow, it was dark, rich and super chocolatey, without being too sweet.  I also had a Spiced Milk Chocolate Turtle, which was rich and chocolatey with some nice cinnamon flavor.

I love this spot and would recommend it for any person who loves chocolate.  Besides the fact that everything tastes incredible, everything looks incredible too...many of the chocolates are designed with elaborate colors and don't seem like edible pieces.  This is the kind of spot you go to and purchase something to impress someone...I can't wait to go back.
author: Ken G.

description:
Great chocolates! And yes, they are a little pricey, but I think they are worth it. After all, it's pretty art and tasty treats! 

I have always had great customer service here as well. Thanks, CE!
author: Storm A.

description:
The funny part is that I know engineers who make shapes for a living. It is a good gig. And part of me wants to ship a box of these chocolate creations to them for 'research' and inspiration. Perhaps I can be reimbursed.

I always seek out local chocolatiers when visiting a city and Christopher Elbow did not disappoint (even though he's from Kansas). But I kept thinking to myself, is this guy an artist or an engineer? I suspect he is both. 

The chocolate truffles are smooth and silky, but what resonates most are the glorious shapes and the lustrous colors. Some are 'traditional' with fanciful patterns stamped on top, but what really impressed me were the geometric shapes. Some I've seen before, but others seemed new and rather unique.

What is that? 

A dodecahedron, an octagon prism, an elongated pentagonal cupola? I don't know, but if you are a math whiz, you will think this place is hot!

I loved the purple swirling form of the caramel filled with lavender. The clear passion fruit truffle which erupts in color like an exploding comet. All of the truffles are luminous. These are almost to pretty to eat. Almost.
author: Jen K.

description:
This is the chocolate that can make a girl squeal....so I've heard.
  
Actually, this is the best chocolate on Earth.  Not only do they look elegant and creative, but their taste is magnificent! ...And I'm talking about all their different flavors!  
All around perfection comes to mind when I think of CE chocolates!  

Must-have pieces include Venezuelan Spice, Champagne, Caramel Fleur De Sel, Cappuccino, and Rum Raisin.  Hot chocolate drinks are phenomenal here too.  Got to have my Peppermint dark chocolate or Venezuelan Spice drink fix whenever I'm in Hayes Valley.  

Staff is always welcoming and very helpful.  And I'm a fan of their classy-looking lounge area...and bathroom.


To all other Chocolatiers....beware!  The bar has been raised, for me.  
Nothing compares to CE!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Someone was awesome enough to gift me the
DRINKING CHOCOLATE.

Every woman-friend I've shared this with has Freaked Out. We're talkin like WHEREDIDYOUGETTHIS-HOWCANIGETSOME.

The chocolates range in epicness, i.e. the 4 stars. They rotate, and the best are:
Passionfruit caramel
Lavender caramel
Fleur de sel
Fortunata
Pineapple

But get the Drinking Chocolate for someone.
Or yourself...
and make it thick -
Mmmmmmm.
author: Maria A.

description: Excellent, quality chocolates, and beautiful works of art! Definitely recommend for a special treat and/or gift.
author: Bridget B.

description:
I never thought I would spend so much on chocolates but I was delighted to shell out $32 for 16 pieces of these beautifully handcrafted dark decadence.  Christopher Elbow is HEAVENLY!!!  I feel like I'm on cloud 9 whenever I'm eating CE chocolates.  Once I have tasted CE chocolates, I never want to have any other chocolates again.  Yup the bar has been raised.  

Each piece of chocolate is like a piece of artwork and they tasted yummilicious!!!  The dark chocolate shell has the right firmness with the perfect sweet bitter taste.  Each piece has a unique filling and I've tried almost all the flavors in store right now.

I definitely prefer the chocolate ganache more than the caramel.  Some of my favorites are Champagne, Venezuelan Spice, and Rum Raisin.  

If you're here, you must try their hot chocolate.  Both the peppermint dark chocolate and the Venezuelan Spice were rich and creamy.  Very very good.
author: Hannah C.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday November 15, 2008 @ 3pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Trendy 20-Something Couple in Prada Shades, Rock n' Republic Jeans & Flip-Flops
Decor:  Sleek.  Counter Filled w/ Work of Art Chocolates w/ Samples on Top.  Lounge Area w/ L-Shaped Sofa & Low Cubes
Service:  It Took the Asian Hipster a Few Minutes to Get Off the Phone Before He Helped Us
Imbibe:  Specialty Chocolate Drinks- European Cocoa(A Bit Too Rich)
Devour:  Lavender Caramel &  Fleur de Sel Caramel, Balsamic, Rosemary Caramel  
Total:  $12.50
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Gave it a 4 cuz I didn't like the European hot chocolate I got. The chocolate however is amazing. You can taste the exact flavor without it being weird. Light crispy chocolate shells burst to reveal a delicious unique filling inside. They are the best I've had so far in my chocolate filled life.
author: Kristin N.

description:
Great place
Awesome chocolates 
I like how there is a seating area so if you just can't wait to enjoy your chocolates you can indulge yourself right there
If you are in SF you should make time to visit
author: Max P.

description: The chocolates here are crafted through perfection! I ordered Roasted Hazelnut hot chocolate with the marshmallows, this was best hot chocolate I tried so far, not to thick and not to liquid, perfect texture for me. For a companion to this drink, I ordered hazelnut patty, absinthe bon bon, banana bon bon, and lemon bon bon, ALL OF THEM were AMAZING! The chocolates melted on your tongue and it compliment to the drink that I have. Really enjoyed the feeling when the chocolate melted In my mouth, absolutely make me more addicted to the chocolates! Definitely going back here to try everything!
author: Ibnu A.

description: Decent size selection, great pieces, nice assortment of pre-packaged gift items. They make a pretty good hot chocolate and latte.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
If I ever meet Christoper Elbow, I'd have a talk with this man. 

He'd be stewing over some new chocolate and I'd tap him on the shoulder.

"Sir! Did hard liquor inspire your chocolates?", I'd ask.

And then he'd look at me oddly with a cock-eye as if to tell me to run along... and I'd go back to gingerly sipping my hot chocolate.


Yes, they have decadent DARK DARK DARK HOT CHOCOLATES!

Split the Venezuelan spice  and Orange Chocolate hot chocolate w/ Sherman W. and Timothy H. . . it is INTENSE. DO NOT OPERATE HEAVY OBJECTS AFTERWARD - GET A DESIGNATED DRIVER intense! I couldn't finish the orange (very sweet and orangey), the Venezuelan spice was a bit more manageable but yowaz... 

They also have chocolate coffees... and lots of interesting hot chocolates ... was tempted to get the 85% dark chocolate. They also have a curry hot chocolate and chinese 5 spice one.. very different huh! I'm giving this place 4 stars because their drinks are just so crazy.


They do have a good amount of sample chocolate pieces... so it's fun to taste them. =) They're so pretty!!! But way expensive... it's like $5 for 2 small pieces... not on my "can afford" list. =(
author: Mimi C.

description: I like this shop, and the chocolates are good. They are very pricy but I don't mind shelling out for the dark chocolate sea salt turtles. They are so amazing. They make great gifts and never had a less than enthusiastic responses from the receiver of these. They make a milk chocolate version if one prefers that.
author: Piper W.

description:
Got a little bored today, so late afternoon, decided to take a little wander out of the Castro and ended up in Hayes Valley.  Of course, first stop was the Blue Bottle kiosk, where even though it was a standard cool windy SF day, I picked up a New Orleans iced...mmm, chicory and coffee.  Kept wandering around Hayes and passed Elbow's, which I have seen many times after dinners in the area, but when they've always been closed. Chocolate, coffee...are you thinking what I'm thinking?

The service: I didn't get quite the attitude that some of the other folks have received, but I didn't get quite the most responsive service either.  Sure, the girl was helpful in describing some of the chocolates in front of me, and offered up a sample of the butter pecan truffle, but despite mentioning that I was having coffee, and was contemplating what would go with it, I never got the suggestion of "Oh, X pairs wonderfully with coffee."  I ended up having to make my own observation that most of the flavored truffles probably wouldn't go with the coffee, and I just got a non-committal stare.  Really?  C'mon, chocolate and coffee, this is one of the perfect pairings and one any good chocolatier would seize upon to at the very least upsell me on some psychotically expensive single-sourced dark.

Instead, I found myself having to ask specifically about their plain chocolates, and was just told at most the percentage of cacao in each of them (because Madagascar 64% wasn't obviously 64% cacao...).  No description of flavor profile or anything like that.  In the end, thinking I'd want something to help balance the chicory of the coffee, I went with the Madagascar 64%, and picked up a milk chocolate hazelnut disc for later as well.

I took my purchase and left, thinking that maybe I was getting attitude for bringing other food into the store, and sat down over on the Octavia median.  I will say, the truffle melted pretty well and was darn delicious with the coffee - and as I predicted, the extra milk helped balance the bitter of the chicory and highlighted some of the bright notes in the coffee, while the darker tones of chocolate stood out to me.

I just devoured the hazelnut disc, which was also pretty delicious, with little flecks of crunchiness in the truffle.  One thing I noticed with both chocolates though was that the exterior enrobing chocolate doesn't really like to melt in the mouth.  WIth the Madagascar, I assumed it was a combination of being a cool windy day and a cooler mouth due to the iced coffee, but I noticed the same with the hazelnut.  I know that the darker and more pure cacao a chocolate is, the less it will melt as opposed to dissolve, but I would hope that the milk at least would do so.  Not quite so much.

So ultimately, the chocolates themselves get a 4.5, while the lackluster (but at least not downright rude) service gets a 2 in my book.  I think 3 stars is a pretty decent compromise.  If you're going to sell me fancy $2-a-pop one-bite truffles, at least be willing to know and react to what people are eating/drinking/asking for.
author: Mark C.

description:
Good things come out of Kansas City. Who would have thought? I traveled there for business and it was like an emerging Emeryville. Anyhows, I was happy when I found out that Christopher Elbow was from KC. I think the Midwest gets a bad rap sometimes.

A visit to Christopher Elbow Chocolates is like going to the jewelry store. The chocolates are glossy and enticing, laid out like gold. I sampled the Venezuelan Spice and not only was it delicious, it was beautiful! I bought my friend some chocolate. She only wanted one piece but one chocolate is sad, so I bought her two. I'm a big spender. I also treated to a round of liquid chocolate. To my surprise, the hot chocolate wasn't as thick as i thought it was going to be. It was drinkable.

I chose the coconut curry hot chocolate. It was amazing like a trip to the Far East. It definitely smells like curry and is even sprinkled with curry powder on the top. I was a little afraid of my first sip but the smell and taste actually worked itself out. The smell is pungent and the taste is earthy and divine. I think the coconut milk has something to do with it. It's richer than whole milk. Anyhows, it was a five star drink. My only complaint was that it could have been served in a nicer cup. The paper cup cheapened the drink. In any case, whatever variation of hot chocolate you order, it is made with more care than any world class cup of java.

The seating area is amazing. This is a true chocolate bar with box lighted tables and dark wood. The lounge and shop is never crowded so pretty much whether you are shopping or sipping, you will have peace, quiet, full customer service and privacy.
author: Rachel A.

description:
After a not so subtle hint, my husband ordered a Valentine's Day box of chocolates for me this year...probably my first in 5 years together. And he did it so right. 
I can't wait until next year! No, really...I may have to treat myself between now and then and I hear they have excellent hot chocolate.
author: Carnley P.

description:
If you want chocolate that takes like is was made be a frikken magical wizard, this is the place!

There is no better!
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Chocolate Truffle-licious Orgasmica anyone? *Raises Hand* ME, ME, ME!!!

No words can describe how intricately designed and sinfully decadent Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolates (CEAC) are. These designer chocolates are so effen good that it will make every one of your senses tingle.

I've passed by CEAC many times while having lunch in Hayes Valley and it wasn't until yesterday did I finally pay a visit.

Upon entering, my eyes were fixated at the glass cases filled with miniature pieces of chocolate art and my head became discombobulated on what to choose. I opted to get a 9-piece box and choose the following:

*Champagne: An alcoholic's delight; rich and smooth w/ a velvety ganache center and a prominent Champagne flavor. 

*Fleur De Sel: OMG--YUM! When you bite into it, the caramel flows like hot lava on to your tongue and melts into your taste buds. The sea salt highlights the caramel flavor and leaves an ever so light salt flavor on your palette. 

*Hazelnut: Heavenly! The hazelnut ganache is velvety smooth w/ hazelnut tibits for a slight crunch. Sorry, Ferrero Rocher, CEAC has you beat!

*Cappuccino: A dessert perfectly matched for a coffee addict. The cappuccino chocolate has a light, airy, and smooth ganache center w/ a strong espresso bite to it. 

*Wildflower Honey: OMG, how is it possible that something can change flavors? Upon biting into the Wildflower Honey, you can taste the strong honey smell and as it melts in your mouth, the "honey" transforms to a creamy sweet caramel taste. DELISH!

*Ghana: For dark chocolate fans; the Ghana is rich, velvety, w/ a slightly bitter after taste. 

*Macadamia Praline: YUMMY! The caramelized macadamia nuts are blended w/ silky chocolate ganache for a perfect blend of sweet, nutty, and buttery taste.

*Venezuelan Spice: MUY CALIENTE! At first, the Venezuelan Spice taste like the regular CEAC ganache; rich and velvety, however as it melts away you can feel the spice catch up to you as it leaves a fiery kick on your palette. 

*Dulce De Leche: Creamy, milky, and sweet. If you like flan or are a Vietnamese ice coffee fan, you will like the Dulce De Leche as has a taste very similar to condensed milk.

Although CEAC has about 25 different flavors to choose from, each with its own unique flavor profile and taste, the quality for each is very consistent. Whether the star ingredient is champagne, honey, chili, or a nut, its taste is prominent and shines through the velvety sweetness of the chocolate ganache w/o overpowering it. CE definitely did a superb job of matching chocolate with different ingredients that work in harmony with one another. 

The chocolates are beautifully boxed and a picture brochure is included so you can differentiate one chocolate from another. 

CEAC are a bit pricey at about $2/piece, but are worth every penny considering the quality and care it took to make these exquisite culinary miniature delights. 

We all know all the money in the world can't solve our problems, but chocolate can (well, at least in my book it can). So, if you're in the doghouse, do yourself a favor and pick up a box of CEAC for your significant other b/c nothing says "I Love You" more than a mouthful of cavities. 

And, to the men who need a helping hand w/ their women *AHEM*, bring your lovely lady some CEAC and problem SOLVED! Guaranteed...*Wink Wink*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
A family member introduced me to this fabulous chocolatier a couple of years ago during a brief visit to the City. 

He took me again in May, after a long walk and an early dinner when it started to get chilly. Each of us had the liquid chocolate, you get to choose the style and flavor. 

It was the most amazing "hot chocolate" I've had and I've had many... I opted for the European style passion fruit flavor with a homemade marshmallow. Divine.

Yes, the chocolates and truffles are delectable and look so good it's hard to eat them. They're wonderful. Of course, these are the main show. However, their liquid chocolate offerings are going to keep my family and me coming back for more! 

We lounged in the back, chatting and relaxing before we made our way back through Hayes Valley and up the hill.

Thanks for the chocolate finery! I will be taking more family members this July!
author: T M.

description:
Am I the only one bugged out by highly decal'd and decorated food objects? Like, when the chocolates look more like intergalactic marbles and twee hipster snuff boxes than my beloved edible brown stuff, I just don't really feel it, yanno? It doesn't look appetizing anymore. Simultaneously as an artist, I'm thinking oh my gosh how long did it take those wee elves to paint three flowers on every single one of these truffles?! I'm not going to disrespect their work by just popping the darn thing in my mouth. Hermione would be proud.

Elves rights aside though, I will concede this place made me overcome my aversion of pretty chocolate. As a matter of fact, I may have already developed a Pavlovian salivating response to the sight of pastel colors on dark brown squares. The chocolates here are RIDICULOUS. They just melt in this crazy way like they're just filled with chocolate butter. And maybe they are but oh my god just wow. They have an intimidating lineup of flavors, and equally intimidating prices standing in the way of me just trying them all. But you got me Elbow, you got me good. Chocoholics Anonymous here I come.
author: Carol C.

description: Great drinking chocolate and bonbons. My only complaint is I prefer my drinking chocolate without bubbles.
author: P T.

description: Delicious specialty chocolates. Very pricey. But a nice treat/indulgance
author: Pidge M.

description:
The time was 5:20pm. My boyfriend & I came in around 40mins before closing..not 10mins before closing. Neither of the two girls working replied nor looked enthused when we said "hi". I wanted to see what $40 of the chocolate would get me. Well, for starters, it gave me a cold welcoming *intentional eye contact was snubbed*

Because the Black girl was organizing the baked goods, we got help (if you want to call it that..) from the Asian girl. We're first time Christopher Elbow customers..and it probably showed when we asked if there was a section of dark chocolates. "They're all dark chocolates," she replied..and I'm sure her attitude included an eye-roll behind her long bangs. Okay! Attitude--double-check!

-when we asked what type ONE choclate heart was..she got annoyed we didn't hear her the first time--when she literally sped-BARKed the types available (I'm sorry..are we taking up your time? *checks for other customers..none*)
-"Fleur de..what..what type of chocolate is that?" *esperated sigh" "flower of salt...???"

We didn't have to go down too far to agree with fellow Yelpers that the customer service, especially for high-end chocolates..especially in Hayes Valley..needs either a retraining session OR the Boot!

Customer Service is the face of your business.
First impression resulted in a lost customer..which is sad because I BLEED chocolate..

Ooo..macaroons *walks up the street*
author: Denise J L.

description:
Stopped by here to pick up beautiful chocolates to give to the boyfriend's parents. This is an awesome place to splurge and buy decadent chocolate :)

There are so many choices here- you can buy pre-packaged chocolate or make your own custom box. I bought a custom box of 9 pieces for $20. They included:
Passion Fruit
Spiced Mango
Hazelnut Praline
Raspberry
Macadamia Praline
Peanut Praline
Citrus Tea
Brown Butter Pecan
Persia

They are all so elegant looking- perfect to impress anyone!
author: Elaine T.

description: Absolutely delicious chocolates. Every time I come here I go straight for the lemon chocolates. They are out of this world amazing and I am so happy that they came back for good! The employees are sweet and love to talk to you It really completes the whole experience. The chocolate is $2-$3 per piece but it is worth every penny.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I didn't have enough money to try any of their chocolates because the only reason why I came here was for their hot chocolate. My friend and I came in around closing time and there was no one else in there. They have a nice selection of hot chocolates to try. My friend opted for their original hot dark chocolate while I decided to try their coconut milk curry spice hot chocolate. The interior of the shop is so clean and the display of chocolates is so seductive, but they're $2 a piece.

All of their hot chocolates are priced at $4.50 which is kind of expensive for me, but totally worth it. My coconut milk curry spice hot chocolate was so good, I've never experienced these flavors together before, but it was awesome. It was like the curry flavor hits your taste buds first, then it's followed with a deep dark chocolate that is just delicious. My friend really enjoyed her hot chocolate as well and we had the chance to just chill inside their store for a little bit even though it was past closing time.

We had a good experience with the workers; they didn't rush us at all and were very hospitable. I need to come back again to try their chocolates!
author: Lauren L.

description:
Chocolates that look like jewels from a king's treasure trove! And they taste like they were from some mythical story about royalty. They are truly out of this world amazing and delectable. 

Pricey and oh so worth it. Great variety but not overwhelming. 

TRY THE SIPPING CHOCOLATE!!! The spicy Venezuelan is fab done with full fat milk and a huge, handmade marshmallow on top. 

The store is so elegant and yet welcoming and approachable. Its on a busy corner so walk there. 

They have a great lounge so you can sip your chocolate and read a novel, catch up on your newspaper or just sit and watch the world go by. Its a peaceful respite in that bustling 'hood. It'd be a great place for part of a date: different, romantic and somewhat reassuring.

Amanda is a great lady behind the counter and makes learning about chocolate a ton of fun. They even have a discount card. 

If you want to impress someone in love, business or for Mother's Day, get Elbow Chocolates. The boxes are as artfully prepared as the chocolates. There is so much old world care & beauty mixed with nouveau charm its an intoxicating mix.

After working in the area for most of 2015, they came to know me by name and, were even kind enough to make me a sipping chocolate to purchase and pick up! I just had to call ahead. What great old fashioned service!!! I'd be running late to work and would zip in, pay and waltz off with my cup of energy in hand. Marvelous! 

And, if you want to pay it forward, and sneak to pay for someone else to surprise them and make their day, they will do it. Its fun to treat total strangers who will never know you and make life sweeter for them. Christopher Elbow chocolates make the world a better place.
author: F M.

description: The most amazingly beautiful & tasty chocolate selection plus incredible customer service!
author: Brielle J.

description:
Got chocolates here twice.  Maybe have tried about 16 different ones?  Mostly dark chocolate based

1. Turtles are very good - A-
2. 3-D dome-ish ones generally are pretty good - B
3. Flat square ones are ok - C  

Some how the dome ones are more flavorful than the flat square ones.  
They are really quite good (esp the dk turtles).  But the others leave me a little wanting.  And it's pricey.

Will I be back?  Yup, most likely  = )  Is this my favorite place?  No.  The quest for the most amazing chocolate ever is still in effect!  Hai-Yah!  

[Midwest: Tabor Hill is similar in concept]
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this!! What else I can say about Christopher Chocolate.
Pretty, Delicate, Elegant, and Super Delicious and Smooth

I got 16piece box!! It was just too pretty to eat. 
Pistachio, Caramel with Fleur de Sel, Venezuelan Spice are my favorite. 

one star has been taken off because the price. Sad :(
author: JustinE Y.

description: Pricey chocolate, but they gave me a sample truffle (forgot the flavor but it had some spice to it) and was delicious.  Staff was cordial but not particularly welcoming.
author: Arthur A.

description: These are the prettiest chocolates ever. I picked the one displayed on the poster in the window. Yummy! They have hot chocolate and coffee drinks. I recommend the mocha made with rich, delicious chocolate. And given the choice between a marshmallow or whipped cream on top, I opted for the marshmallow! Duh!  They have a relaxing seating area. Enjoy your visit!!i
author: Jill M.

description:
Beautiful!

This review is only based off of the store, the looks of the chocolates, and the customer service.

I bought an assortment of their beautifully packaged and screened chocolates with exotic flavors for my equally beautiful hostess who generously let me and my boyfriend stay at her place for the weekend.

What is a better surprise than her finding a box of these gorgeous gems on her bed pillow when she walks home after a long and tiring day of watching her boyfriend play paintball? (haha)  

Well, she LOVED them!  She still hasn't grown the balls to eat them yet, but just knowing that Christopher Elbow's lovely artisanal chocolates made her day just a bit brighter makes this place totally worth it.

Almost too beautiful to eat?  Well, for my dianadarling, they happen to be!
author: Mindy H.

description:
If they never changed a thing, I would probably still love them. Fortunately for me, Christopher Elbow likes to shake things up a bit. On a recent visit, I bought a selection that included their turtles (yum!) and the floowing truffles:
Grapefruit (fresh grapefruit juice and zest blended into a creamy caramel),
Raspberry (a layer of fresh raspberry pate de fruit topped with a dark chocolate-raspberry infused ganache),
Fresh Lemon (fresh lemon marmalade and lemon infused white chocolate ganache),
Passion Fruit (caramel made with the tropical taste of passion fruit),
Citrus Tea (dark chocolate ganache infused with black tea and fresh orange zest), and
Butterscotch Bourbon (brown sugar caramel infused with Kentucky Bourbon). Old flavors or new, you can count on bright clean flavors, luscious textures, and eye-catching colors to brighten your day and keep you coming back, I just wish the folks who worked their actually acted like they wanted to be there. I've been their dozens of times and encountered maybe two friendly people. I know if I was working in a chocolate shop, I  would be naturaly happy. That's whyThat why four stars not five. Definitely recommended for chocolate lovers.
author: Nicole M.

description: I love this place and when it's ballet season, chances are you'll find me in here most Saturday afternoons. The truffles are pricey but worth it, in my opinion, and the hot chocolate -- DELICIOUS! You have to get it with a marshmallow! Seating is limited but you can take your hot chocolate to go.
author: Mariel G.

description:
If you fancy exotic and creative chocolate truffles, you will have to try Christopher Elbow. I have had most of their truffles and there are very few I do not like. All of their chocolate truffles have very distinct flavor. If you are a chocolate purist or traditionalist, you might find the fillings overwhelming. Consider these chocolates a dessert dish of its own kind.  

Every piece is artistically designed and beautifully crafted. They look impressive and they taste wonderful. The texture of the chocolate shell and the truffle filling are perfect. Their fruity ones are unlike other chocolatiers. The fillings are refreshing and crisp! Not overly chocolaty yet don't taste like some fruit jam. Try Bananas Foster or Caramel apple and you will see what I mean.
author: Mona W.

description:
This is a true addiction and I'm not going to give it up any time soon.
I discovered Christopher Elbow watching a special on tv a few years back on artisanal chocolate making and he's one of the purest forms of it.
The level of passion, creativity and quality he puts into his creations is impressive and one of a kind.
I love that Dean & Deluca also sells in Napa if you're out that way.
A must experience even if you order online, you won't be disappointed and everyone I've introduced to this divine experience has hated and loved me for it : )
author: Candy G.

description: I *REALLY* wanted to do something nice for my sister, who lives 3,000 miles away.  And ever since I first saw these chocolates, I was smitten.  Well, she just opened the chocolates and I am a very happy camper.  I honestly don't think there is another choice if you really want to thank or impress someone.  10 Stars.
author: Matt T.

description: If you're lucky, they might be giving away samples! The chocolates here will send your taste buds on a wild journey. Hayes Valley is lucky to be the home of a Christopher Elbow Chocolate shop. All of his other stores are in Kansas City!
author: Amy M.

description:
I absolutely love the liquid chocolate drinks and they leave me craving more.  They are among the most expensive hot chocolates of all time served in the smallest cup I've seen.  I just wish I could order five or six at once, but I would very poor if I did. They sell chocolate powder, but I'm hesitant at making this drink on my own. I don't have the fancy equipment.

I've tried the solid chocolates as well. They are very pretty and would make an excellent gift. But when you drop in to purchase a box of chocolates, don't forget the liquid chocolate for yourself. Cheers.
author: Nathan E.

description:
As an impromptu Val's day gift when we were in the city, my husband let me pick a few things out at this store. I opted for the dark chocolate turtles and a hazelnut square and he picked up a dark chocolate peanut butter square. When we were in the store, we were given the chance to try a straight up chocolate truffle that was quite delicious, however, I really wanted the turtles and was trying not to let the store get the best of my waistline..
Hubby didn't like his peanut butter square as the consistency of the PB was very creamy, so much so that it "foamed" in his mouth as he described it. I enjoyed my hazelnut square, but it wasn't my favorite.
The best were the dark chocolate turtles, or should I say, hockey pucks. The things were literally ginormous! I think we paid about $15 for the six of them, which sounds like a lot, but really, if you knew how big they were, you wouldn't think the price was that bad. Loved the caramel and nuts but what really did these turtles an honor was the sprinkling of sea salt on the top that really contrasted nicely with the chocolate and caramel (and I'm not usually a sea-salt caramel top of gal; I don't love it when it's heavy handed.) 
If I was back in the area I'd go again to grab a box of these for a special occasion.
author: Rachel B.

description: How have I not written a review of Christopher Elbow yet?  Best hot chocolate around.  I buy the canisters of the Venezuelan Hot Chocolate so I always have some at home.  When at the store, I always have them make me a hot chocolate, too.  Try the coconut curry.  Sounds weird, but is delicious.  The Chinese 5 spice is and the spicy hot chocolates are also very good.  Their chocolates are good as well.  Expensive, but worth it if you love chocolate.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Such beautiful chocolates and the best drinking chocolates!  The service is warm and welcoming and they offer samples!  Loved this place while visiting San Francisco!
author: Nan W.

description: In a city blessed with many good chocolatiers Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolates stand out for having some of the prettiest design on their chocolates and a light hand with the flavours. They are a reasonable price for  tiny luxuries and a wonderful treat at $2 a piece. Sure you would be eating these by the handful like M&M's but they aren't meant to be eaten that way.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
AMAZING! I am a huge chocolate fan. This place blew me away! Not only did they sell artisan chocolates, but they also make yummy hot chocolate. Tried the spicy hot chocolate & original hot chocolate. 

If you want a kick, get the spicy,  but if you're looking for that rich, dark chocolate-y, go for the original.

Most of their chocolates are $2/piece. Although small, they're full of flavor. 

I can't wait to come here again. They also have a little lounge/seating area to enjoy your hot chocolate in! It's great fun.
author: Veronica S.

description: Yum chocolate.. Over priced but if you got the funds indulge in some flavors.  Fancy sweets great for gifts
author: Sandra S.

description:
I was thinking of a chocolate gift for Valentine's Day and this place came up in my search. I memorized each one I wanted after reading Yelp reviews, so I picked each one of the 9 pieces I got.

The chocolate tastes really clean and it has the prefect texture. I like earl grey and venezuelan spice. Didn't try the Caramel with Fleur de Sel, but it's W's favorite, so I gotta try that one next time. I don't really like the macadamia pralines and hazelnut for some reason, I think it distracts me from tasting the chocolate itself... and I usually lovelove a lot of nuts in my chocolate.

The place looks nice, but I think they need more seating area. But then since most people come to grab the chocolates bonbons, limited seating isn't really a big issue.
author: Novalina N.

description:
I love the fact that this place appears to be so bourgeois but when you walk in, you are warmly greeted. There is no snotty attitude, no upturned noses, just damned good chocolate. This is coming from a girl who doesn't even LIKE chocolate, mmmkay?
I sampled the jasmine tea chocolate thingamabobber and it was really rich but not in the overwhelming sense.
I bought 2 patties and told myself to get out of there because i'd probably spend an entire paycheck buying gifts for people.
The guy with the handle bar mustache - YOU'RE COOL.
author: Susy C.

description: Top rate artisanal chocolate shop - gorgeous creations that are as yummy as they look. Their Easter egg samplers are dazzling and irresistible!  We got a salted caramel sample that was so delicious as were the others we purchased.
author: Linnet T.

description:
Every time I buy these chocolates (for a White Elephant party for example), the event becomes part showing, part jealousy fit.  People can't help but want them and want to look at them.  Very pretty and great for gifts.  

My gf bought these for her boss's birthday.  But we were unable to pick up the day before the big office lunch party.  This was a dreadful no-no; the store doesn't even open till noon.  Plus, her boss isn't just the manager, he's the CEO so it was kind of a big deal.  In desperation, I emailed the address on the website in the evening, asking if there was any possibility of picking up early in the morning.  It was a long shot - a request that's last minute AND unusual PLUS the email goes to the Kansas City location.  But sure enough, the good people of Christopher Elbow came through and somehow made it happen!  Day saved!  

Top points for the sweets.  And even more, for the exceptional customer service.
author: Emit S.

description: THE BEST! We have been back many times and I really love every chocolate we've tried. You have to try the Port Wine Fig, Whiskey Walnut , Persia and the Lemon. I actually LOVE all of them! Try everything!!
author: Diane W.

description:
Right now. Halfway through my quest to find the best S.F. artisan chocolate I would rate CE top. He still has to compete with my Swiss chocolate taste which I acquired from birth living near Switzerland.
Forget about the paintbrush markings. Personally I find those rather distracting from the taste of the chocolate. [Think about it. Most wine bottles and wine stickers are very low profile.]
I tried all of their confections and they pack it in a nice box. This is good to very good chocolate. 
The only two objections I have is that it doesn't fully cater to my taste and what I am used to but they are also too creamy. Personally I find a creamy quality as sign of pretense, just like the airbrush painting. It takes away from the real taste of the chocolate ganash and find flavors. Creamy is like flushing it all down at once. It's like a small fireworks but too much to take it all on at once. So what is left is the last color/taste you have experienced. The best of chocolates I can keep in my mouth for 1-2min and each second a different flavor develops and plays with different previous flavors. CE makes very good chocolate. It's not the best chocolate I ever had nor the best chocolate in the US.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Came here with friends as one of the stops for dessert hopping through SF after finals. 
Nothing like a cup of hot chocolate to warm you up! I got the hazelnut infused one.It was luxuriously rich... too rich almost but so are all pure hot chocolates... its nothing like that nesquik  instant powder mix business.  I've had thick hot chocolates before at Max Brunner's in NY and in Angelina's in Paris. For first timers it may be too much. I do suggest sipping water along with it otherwise share with a friend because my cup despite it being presented in a normal paper cup was too much for me despite how much of a chocolate fiend I am as well. 

This isn't even the highlight of the show which is of course the chocolates.  Chocolates almost too pretty to eat and they have a very modern feel to them with how they are shaped and decorated. They would be the perfect gift box set for any chocolate junkie that you want to impress ;). 


At $2.00 a piece its on the moderate pricing for gourmet chocolates. 
The one's I sampled include:
1) Carmel with Fleur de Sel- it's claimed as the best selling chocolate they have and it was pretty good. It comes in a cute quirky geometric 3D shape  I knew i would like it because I love the Tully's dark chocolate salted caramel Mocha and it almost tastes like an identical more concentrated version of that!  

2)Macadamia Praline- Delicious well I love anything with Macadamia nuts in it 

3) Extra Dark- I am a Dark chocolate Junkie and this was all the while better with ganache in it :D. 

It is a little bit out of my way but I would definitely come swing by again if chance presents itself!
author: Sharon Y.

description:
Exceptional chocolate. 
The white chocolate passionfruit truffle is phenomenal, so is the Fleur de sol.
Prices are a bit elevated but worth it for a treat.
author: M E.

description:
Quality investment.

Some of the most innovative and artful chocolates in the city. Sampled the Passion Fruit with a caramel center and Winter Spice. Superb looking and tasting.

But it doesn't come cheap. Two bucks a square seemed on the high side.

No question about the quality. Now if we could only get a bit more quantity.
author: Jason B.

description:
How can chocolate be bad? Especially beautiful artisanal chocolate
These tiny little chocolates are so pretty to look at and taste so delicious, too.
I had the dulce de leche and a cherry. Yummy! I thought I would love the dulce de leche and i did. My only complaint is that their pieces aren't bigger, but that's just the American in me talking. 
Plus, the guy who owns this place was Emeril Lagasse's pastry chef. Whoa!
author: dina s.

description:
I had three chocolates from CEAC, and did not attain enlightenment, have three wishes granted, or slowly levitate off the ground and shoot rainbows from my from finger tips.

At $2 per tiny chocolate, I was expecting something amazing to happen. Maybe a full gospel choir to follow me around humming "sweet chariot"  or be serenaded by a green leprechaun that looks like Kanye West.

As a chocolate, they were good. But when it's cheaper to fill up my Learjet with 300 gallons of baby seal tears then buy a sampler box - "good" doesn't seem good enough.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Pricey but delicious dark chocolate peanut butter patty.

If they were open past 10 p.m. this would make a great dessert-date spot.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Yes there are tons of cute chocolates with odd shapes and colors and flavors.  However, it was a brisk day so I went directly for the liquid chocolate.  HUGE selection of flavors with such a great base.

Ginger Liquid Chocolate: So creamy and decadent, definitely beats any powdered cocoa you've had from a Swiss ho before!  The ginger added a great fiery kick to help cut the milk fat goodness.  The fresh whipped cream needs some serious whipping though because it was more like just regular cream.

Mint Liquid Chocolate: Just as indulgent as the ginger, but with a softer peppermint flavoring.  Wasn't overpowering which is a good thing.  Same issue with the whipped cream.
author: Adam B.

description: Let's just say that  the hot chocolate is like crack.  I give Chris Elbow Chocolates as gifts for foodies and others who have everything.  They are like little jewels.  Absolutely a treat and worth every expensive cent.
author: Jan E.

description:
Some people really know how to make me a fat person. Christopher Elbow is one of those people. 
These little chocolates are a lot more like jewels that you win for turning over money that you have little better use for. The presentation-- the colors, the design, are impressive enough, but then you eat some and wow! The experience is very special. 

A personal favorite of mine is the hot chocolate. I could give up any number of other vices just to continually enjoy this hot chocolate. Hmmm... so incredible. Very rich, very special, and a great treat that I give myself just for making it over to Hayes Valley. 

The downside/upside to this place is, too bad we don't have one in my neighborhood. But the upside is, it's a destination out of reach enough to make it safe for my waistline.
author: Kelly B.

description:
My mouth just exploded.  No, really - I just took a bite of  chocolate that had pop rocks in it.  Pop rocks!!  Now, that's some fun chocolate.

Christopher Elbow is the newest purveyor of handmade, artisinal chocolates to grace our city of chocolate-lovers.  In the space formerly known as "Friend", the modern aesthetic has been preserved and freshly appointed in deep red, bright white, and, of course, dark chocolate brown.   I don't know if it's because of the company's Midwestern roots, but the environment feels very laid-back and grounded, which is not always the case in similar high-end stores.

The corner location works well for the set up of a pristine chocolate counter, with an ever-so-clean display of the chocolates.  It's extremely easy to shop, whether you just want a few morsels or a gift box.  There is also a wall filled with chocolate bars and other products like pate de fruit.

The flavors are interesting and tempting, from the comforting (bananas foster) to the exotic (strawberry balsamic caramel).  Someone in the kitchen definitely has an appreciate for alcohol (someone after my own heart, clearly), as there are confections which contain everything from wine to scotch to absinthe.   Colors and shapes are artistic and interesting - I especially liked the jewel tones of the lavender caramel and absinthe chocolates.  If you like fleur de sel, you can find it on turtles and in caramels.

They also offer drinkable chocolate, in an impressive variety of flavors.  And one thing that really sets them apart from other chocolatiers is that they have a chocolate lounge - so that you can take a seat, flip through a magazine, and sip or eat your chocolate in a relaxed environment.  

I indulged in a cup of hot chocolate with passion fruit - so rich, so creamy with just a hint of passion fruit flavor - it was silky and delicious, and if I had to make any improvement, I would add more passion fruit for an even stronger bite.

Each of the chocolates I have tried so far has been delicious - Fresh Lime, Strawberry Balsamic Caramel, and Macadamia (I think) with Pop Rocks.  I love their tiny size and concentration of flavors.  

Be sure to stop by Christopher Elbow next time you are in Hayes Valley - and for you chocolate connoisseurs, it is worth a special trip.  I think that this Valentine's Day, there is no one more deserving of a box of CE chocolates than you.  And, of course, me!
author: Liz S.

description: Didn't get her name, but the staff who helped us was so cool. thanks for the samples. We love the chocolates you recommended, still savoring it after a week!
author: Food L.

description:
Wow. This is really excellent chocolate. Really smooth, rich, decadent...Heavenly. :)

I've walked by this store for what feels like forever. (2 years.) And the other day, I was all, Screw it., I'm going in.

The price gave me pause. ($10 for a box for four teeny chocolates?) But I considered it well worth it. And I'm a pretty frugal gal ;)

The customer service wasn't anything special. Eh. But unfortunately, I'll deal with that, because these little squares=a mouthgasm.

I didn't try the liquid chocolate. I don't mess with hot chocolate.
author: Ashley P.

description: C.E. Artisanal Chocolates is, FOR SURE, a Chocoholic's paradise... Upon walking in, i was in awe by the delicate, and sophisticated designs. I had to buy a couple of pieces, so I tried the extra dark for $2, and the fleur de sel turtle for $3 (which has been appearing in my dreams for the past two nights). I must say, it was the most decadent $5.00 i've ever forked over. Move over, Godiva -Christopher Elbow is where it's at!
author: Tricia A.

description:
Let me preface this review with the fact that I am a certified chocoholic. Being such, let's just say this place is good...not just 'regular' scharffenberger good...but more like supercalifragilisticexpialidocious good.

Now that we've got that squared away...head down there and get your choco high on.  The Venezuelan Spice chocolates and turtles are definitely little pieces of heaven.  Wash that down with their mindblowingly tasty hazelnut hot chocolate and you will be flyin' high...Guaranteed.
_________________________________________________________________

UPDATE:  Just tried the Venezuelan Spice Hot Chocolate.  If you are a fan of Mexican Hot Chocolate...this is the ultimate drink for you!!!  The combination of sweet chocolate and super spiciness will blow the socks off of you and your mama.
author: Justin L.

description:
Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolate shop in SF is Finally open.  He has a store in Kansas City and now it's in SF.

It's a nice, clean shop.  We went on Sat 2/16/08 and there 4 people there to help customers, no Christopher Elbow.  I overheard he'll be there Mon.

They don't give out samples.  His chocolates are hella pretty.

I got a 16 piece box for $32 and I picked all my own pieces.  You can also get a pre-made box, but that's no fun.

2 pc box $5
4 pc box $10
9 pc box $20
16 pc box $32
21 pc box $40

Tried so far: Caramel w/ Fleur De Sel; Persian; Caramel w/ strawberry balsamic; Raspberry.  Raspberry is my favorite so far.  I also liked the Pop Rock Peanut Praline.  Friend told me to get a Fleur de Sel Turtle that's $2.5 ea, I'll get it next time.

Credit cards taken.

Drinking chocolate menu $4.5 a cup.  14 different kinds to choose from.  Menu here:

Americana: Rich, dark chocolate with milk
European style: Rich, dark chocolate with water
Mocha: Dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla
Extra Dark: 85% dark chocolate with milk

Chinese five spice: Dark chooclate, chinese 5-spice powder
Coconut curry: Dark chocolate, coconut milk, curry powder
Ginger caramel: Dark chocolate, ginger, caramel
Orange citrus: Dark chocolate with orange and citrus
Passion fruit: Dark chocolate with passion fruit
Peanut butter: Dark chocolate with peanut butter
Peppermint: Dark chocolate, mint
Raspberry: Dark chocolate, raspberry
Roasted hazelnut: Dark chocolate, hazelnut
Venezuelan spice: Dark chocolate infused with chile and spice

Nice lounge area to sit & relax.  Magazines available to read.

One unisex bathroom to use.
---------
Updated 3/7/08:
Fleur de Sel Turtle is now $3!  Damn, I should have bought it when it was $2.5
Tried Absinthe chocolate-just ok, $2
Tried Orange Blossom Honey - liked it, $2
Got in a bag (cheaper than box) Total $7!

Hrs:
Hours are Mon-Thu 11am-8pm, Fri-Sat 11am-10pm, and Sun 12pm-6pm. 401 Hayes St. at Gough, 415-355-1105.

Website:
http://www.elbowchocolates.com/
author: Ann L.

description:
Chocolate priced this way leads to portion control.

The star of the show was the rosemary chocolate -- an interesting combination that made everyone's eyes get real big as they took the first bite.  Venezuelan spice was ok, but not that complex nor interesting.
author: Dave S.

description: Oh man, this is good stuff! I've become cynical about things named "Artisanal," it's often code word for expensive crap, but this place makes Artisanal proud. The chocolates are like jewels, it's hard to eat them because they are mini-artworks. I tried the Venezuelan chocolate, it was rich and satisfying. Got the turtles to bring home, the Venezuelan had a delicate cinnamon flavor, the Fleur de sel was perfection, the caramel was so rich and had just the right amount of salt. I also got a caramel with salt individual chocolate, which melted in my mouth and left me wanting more. It's expensive, but the product is worth it, the quality is outstanding. I hope I don't go back soon, I can't afford the cost or the calories.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I used to live two blocks from Christopher Elbow --dangerous!  The chocolates are good, though there's some non-trial overlap issues between certain ones.  Go for the exotic ingredients --the Tennessee lavender really pops.

Chocolates are $2/piece for most, and they can pack up a shipping box --complete with ice-packs--if you want to mail someone a gift.  Just be prepared for an extra $25 or so charge.

They have a sitting area and serve hot chocolate, which (aside from location) is the only tactical advantage they have over Cocoa Bella, which sells nearly all Christopher Elbow chocolates, in addition to several dozen others, and is only a few miles away.
author: Charles Y.

description:
I'm not sure what happened, but this place isn't as good as it used to be. The chocolates are amazing, possibly one of the finest, purest, high quality of sweets I have ever had my hands on, but the service has gone down a bit, hence the three stars.

I used to come in here all the time because not only was the chocolate good, but so was the service! Now I don't want to bother coming in unless I pass by and see the usual staff I'm used too.

The time I came in the girl seemed a bit rude and annoyed at my order (liquid hot chocolate.) I was surprised to see her at this store too since she was at the other chocolate company. Anyways, the atmosphere did NOT feel welcoming and inviting like it used to. The chocolates are still great, and maybe if you go on the weekends the liquid hot chocolates will be the high, delicious quality they usually are, but the service is not what it used to be.
author: V V.

description: While I have only sampled the various chocolates, I can attest that the hot chocolates and mocha beverages are amazing. We only discovered this place a week ago and my wife is in fact addicted now and wants one every time we drive by there, perhaps they are infused with some form of crack, I dunno...Don't forget to ask for one of their special yummy marshmallows! Anyways, they are for sure amongst the best mochas and hot chocolates I have had in the city.  I had a nice espresso there today as well.  The chocolate pieces that I have tasted are all excellent, but again, I have not purchased them...We'll surely be back!
author: Andy S.

description:
The chocolates are delicious and fresh, with a great variety of interesting flavours. What's more, is quite a number of them are absolutely beautiful - they're art in chocolate form. The glazes, colours and designs are absolutely amazing. Hell, they look better, and took more skill and artistry to produce than half of the current SF-MoMA collection. And probably taste better too.


Notes:
a) The seating area has managed to replicate the look and feel of an airport lounge, but in a good way. It's at its best on a rainy day.
b) The chocolate is expensive; which is entirely different from being overpriced. If you don't understand why it's this expensive, it's your fault, not the chocolate's.
author: Max R.

description:
I live in Hayes Valley and to me, chocolate falls into the "major food group" just like veggies and fruits.  Money is no object when it comes to chocolate -- I take it very seriously.  So when Christopher Elbow moved into my neighborhood, I was more that thrilled.  This review will be based solely on their chocolate creations.  I have not yet tried their chocolate drinks (no particular reason, I just haven't done it yet).

They have a fairly large selection of beautifully designed creations, each one is a piece of art in and of itself. There's no question that each piece has been meticulously conceptualized and artfully executed.  I'm a marzipan lover but the only thing close to marzipan that he has is the Maple Walnut piece which was delicious -- except all I could taste was the maple -- it overpowered the walnut flavor.  The champagne piece is delightfully designed and quite tasty.  The Rosemary Carmel was delicious also but I could only taste the Carmel and it only barely hinted at Rosemary.  The Vanilla Cognac was also really really good.  The Dark Chocolate Madagascar was sinfully delicious.  

The current menu at Christopher Elbow has about 2 dozen different creations.  Seven of these are caramel based which to me creates an imbalance in their otherwise unique and tasty inventory.  I love a good caramel but with almost one-third of the choices being caramel based, it's a little limiting IMHO.  It is nice that they have a seating area where you can sit and enjoy your purchases right then and there -- which, if you're like me, I would do.

The products are great to give for any occasion -- packaging and presentation are all beautiful and elegant.  The gift of a box of Christopher Elbow chocolates immediately announces that you paid through the nose for these chocolates.  

My critical chocolate loving palate has a couple of complaints but keep in mind that everyone has their own tastes and to enjoy these chocolates requires a fairly sophisticated palate.  I eat a lot of chocolate.  I keep my cardiologist in business because of my love of chocolate.  A few cons:  As earlier mentioned, too many caramel based items; some of the pieces are waaaay to sweet -- so sweet in fact that in some cases you can't even taste anything except sweet.  There are better chocolates in town that are just as good or better but aren't quite as pricey as Christopher Elbow.  Although money is no object for me when it comes to chocolate, I do believe that there is such a thing as "overpriced chocolate."  I don't want to give the impression that these creations are anything other than top of the line excellent but...too sweet can be a deal killer in my book.  They have some really nicely packaged gifty kinds of things (see my pics) too which would make really nice gifts.

When Christopher Elbow first opened shop, service was rude, inefficient and made me feel totally unwelcome.  Thankfully, this attitude has changed and the staff is now much nicer and much friendlier although I still get a sense of snobbery going on behind the counter.  To me that's a HUGE turn off, even if it is for chocolate.  The Cocoa Bella store in the Westfield Shopping Center downtown also carries Christopher Elbow chocolates, so if you don't come out to Hayes Valley, you can go to the mall instead.  

Don't give these to anyone who eats Hershey Kisses, M&Ms or Dove bars. Just don't.

I want to give 5 stars but the fact that there are too many caramel pieces, too many overly sweet things and the snobbery thing going on, I'm afraid I can only give 3 stars.
author: Paul N.

description: One of my top 2 chocolatiers in the city. Everything I've had here has been amazing. I love picking from the pretty little exquisite chocolates. Faves include the passion fruit caramel, earl grey tea, champagne, dark chocolate ganaches. The shells are thin just the way I like. The whole experience is melt in your mouth. After reading some reviews I'm going to branch out and try the fruit pates, hockey pucks and hot/drinking chocolate. Mmm... I think I know where I'm going this avro.
author: Kiki W.

description: This review is solely based on their customer service. I've driven pass this place a couple of times and thought it would be a good idea to come here to buy a Xmas gift for someone that likes chocolate. I was impressed with the store when I walked in. I wanted to try everything but since I was here for a gift I decided I would pass on getting myself something this time. I got a $20 gift box where you got to select 9 chocolates. the lady that helped us was not friendly and looked annoyed the whole time we were selecting our chocolates. She was talking to her coworker half the time and made it seem like we were inconveniencing her by being there. There was another group of people that arrived after us and she gave them the same attitude. I really would like to come back and try their chocolates but I'm turned off by the customer service I received.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Nice shop space, nice shop attendant. Good quality tasted fresh. Pricey yes. But free sample and non pressure selling make it easier to support them at $2/piece or a gift bx for extra $2
author: Lisa C.

description: Looking to buy some artisan chocolate as a gift on Saturday and came upon this shop. The chocolate pieces shines like jewels behind the counter, a real treat to the eyes and they make great gifts. Not a huge fan of the soft centers but the spiced dark chocolate covered almonds knocked me out! Looking forward to try the chocolate drinks on a cold winter day...
author: see L.

description:
What a delightful place to find!!

On the corner of a busy busy street, but the store itself is quiet and pleasant. Very "hip cool" atmosphere. they have a lounging area to sit and enjoy chocolate. how awesome.

I have heard great things about their hot chocolate but after some bikram yoga, drinking hot chocolate wasn't appealing. I knew it was going to be rich and heavy. My friend tried the coconut curry one I believe. which really had the taste of curry. interesting.

Their chocolates were so pretty, we each got a box of 21, i tried most flavors, loved the fluer de sel, cappucino, persia, champagne, macadamia praline...so many yummy ones!

I also noticed that they did mostly dark chocolate! which i LOVE.

prices are a bit on the higher side, but it doesn't hurt to indulge once in awhile right?

parking can be difficult, but the workers there are very nice and knowledgeable!
author: Christine M.

description:
I have walked by it a couple times but never bought actually tried their chocolate until a few weeks ago.

Clearly it was not a busy time when I got there. While I was looking thru the selection, the lady behind the counter was moving truffles from one clear acrylic tray to another identical clear acrylic tray.

All the truffled looked very pretty with vibrant colours. (Where did they get their transfer sheets?)

The price was about average and they were of good quality. I picked up fresh lime, balsamic caramel, spiced pair and mango. I like most of them but somehow the mango flavour was not quite how I like it. It was just personal preference but it was not the variety of mango I like.
author: Cindy B.

description: Amazing airbrushed chocolates. A must see place. So unique and delicious. Try the banana foster chocolate. I also had a hazelnut chocolate thin cookie f
author: Princess Jasmine J.

description:
Yum, yum, yum

Fleur de Sel - silky, dark chocolately with a hint of salt. My favorite!
Fresh Lemon - tart, lemony-white chocolate. A very nice balance. 
Tequila Lime - not too bad but wish the tequila was a bit more prominent
author: Marissa H.

description: Just beautiful little yummy chocolates.  Expensive but I am worth the indulgence.  Oh how I wish I had one or two right now.
author: Michelle A.

description: Great Customer Service! Ambiance is great, and their chocolates are delicious and very cool looking!
author: Charles Z.

description:
You know, I don't really like the real heavy dark chocolate cocoa drinks.

This place serves REAL HEAVY DARK CHOCOLATE.  On one hand, they were actually really good, for the first sip.  After one sip though, I was done.  I have no idea how you're supposed to finish the whole thing.

Wifey and another guy flomped out in the car after having a cup.  It was a quiet, lonely drive....
author: Timothy H.

description: Just bought a $42 dollar box of chocolate and when I asked for a sample they said no! :(  lady at the front was not nice. Usually they're nice, not this time around.
author: J C.

description: One sunday funday while suffering from an extreme case of the munchies, a friend and I wondered in here. I ordered almost one of every piece of chocolate they sold and they were all delicious. I absolutely looooooved the chocolate peanut butter patties. Whoa. Par-Tay-In-My-Mouth.,period. Went back later in the week just to make sure it wasn't the munchies making them so good and YUP, still the best chocolate I've had. And I'm not even that big of a chocolate fan, but ooooh-weee I keep going back for more. A bit pricey but worth every penny!
author: Shari S.

description: Great... actually, fabulous chocolate!  But the people who work there could do with an attitude adjustment.  It's really off-putting to get such snooty and unfriendly service.
author: Diana C.

description:
I had the Venezuelan spiced liquid chocolate. It was really tasty, but almost a little too rich/dense for a drink. I would've preferred they put more milk in it... that way it would've lasted longer too. The servings are quite small and at $4.50 a bit expensive. 

I do think they have an amazing selection of chocolates and think it's a great gift idea... to give or receive ;)
author: Richa A.

description: Stopped by for a last bit of sf hot chocolate love before we went back to socal. I got the hazel nut hot chocolate and my bf got the mocha hot chocolate and both were smashingly delicious! Warning... Very sweet and gets thicker as it cools so drink fast!!!
author: Ashley H.

description:
Came here on a Sunday after stopping by Paulette Macarons and fell in love with their hot chocolate. Finally the 7x7 came through w/ a good winner. The rich, velvety taste is nothing short of fabulous, but you definitely can share a cup with someone else. Next time, i'll have to try their actual chocolates. 

Aside from what they have to offer, I would give their CUSTOMER SERVICE A ONE STAR. The girls behind the counter were not friendly, did not greet acknowledge us or smile, and have their heads so far up their ____ they really need to watch it and get it together. I'm sorry to tell you but you work at a chocolate shop and act like you're at Louis Vuitton. What's worse is that the girl who helped us didn't even do her job correctly. Not once did she ask my friend or me if we wanted the drinks for here or to go. She just assumed and poured our drinks in to go cups. When we asked for a lid, she just pointed across the way to the stand at the door. CHECK YOUR ATTITUDE before you lose business for your store.
author: Kristen C.

description: Our company received a box as a gift from a client. I had the Lavender cream and a Venetian chocolate. Both were fantastic. I especially loved the Lavender. It tastes like a Lavender flower, if that is possible. Heaven to the senses. The best part is you only need one, you could really cut the small candies in two and be completely satisfied. A huge treat! It makes S%&'s taste like Hershey's.
author: Suzanne P.

description:
Oh sweet zombie jesus.  They have great liquid chocolate.  Simply great.  One word of advice: it's better if you order one of the variants without milk.  Really, the whole milk is just unnecessary, and only serves to dampen the rich dark chocolate taste.  I had ginger and caramel in mine, but pretty much all the other options sounded great, and I'll have to try them.

It's a bit pricey at $4.50 for a regular-sized mug, but what do you expect from a place with "artisanal" in their name?
author: Brian T.

description: beautiful looking chocolate -- a work of art.  exotic flavors with an exotic price, made from Valrhona chocolate.  more milk chocolates than dark chocolates in the collection.
author: Rob C.

description:
Very artistic chocolates, a little pricy.  Will be a very nice gift for the holdays this year.  

The rasberry and the currant chocolates and had fruit gels in them, the more fruit I noticed the more intense the flavor.  The fig and port wine was tasty.  The lavender, lime, and the passion fruit were delicious, infused with a strong flavor.  

Tried the 85% dark chocolate bar - a deep toned dark chocolate with faint fruity notes.

My daughter liked the liquid rasberry chocolate, not too sweet as far as hot chocolate goes.
author: John T.

description:
Two words: Chocolate Death.

As Mimi C. mentioned, we went for the Venezuelan Spice and the Orange Citrus hot chocolates:

Venezuelan Spice: Very rich, slightly bitter dark chocolate brew with just a bit of a tingly spicy sensation at the end of each sip.  Delicious!

Orange Citrus: The orange taste is very strong; so strong you're almost beaten over the head with it.  Still pretty good, but the orange needs to be toned down to bring out more of the chocolate flavor of the drink.

So here's where the death part comes in.  Two hot chocolates between 3 people, and we couldn't finish them because they were too rich!  Okay, I guess chocoholics might not have this problem, but we were saturated with sweetness and well on our way to a sugar crash when we left.  So beware!
author: Sherman W.

description:
Christopher Elbow has two retail stores: the first store in Kansas City, Missouri and this second store in San Francisco. Christopher Elbow also sells their chocolate confections through numerous other retailers nationwide. Since the quantity of resellers vastly outnumbers the boutiques run by Christopher Elbow, the focus of the business may be on a mass distribution of a high end chocolate to retailers rather than making an outstanding experience for the customer.

At the entrance of the store, individual truffles form an inviting field of colors and shapes like gems under glass. The colorful candies come in traditional hazelnut, trendy flavors like carmel with salt, and unique products like the Yuzu with Japanese citrus. On my visits, the store always had a wide variety of truffles in stock.  

The drinking chocolate has a technically well executed taste. Smooth, not bitter, consistent, easy to drink. Unfortunately, it also lacks complexity. That's not to say that it's bad, I just felt surprised by the simplicity. It has no citrus finish, no hints of coffee, no earthiness. I expect more from my chocolate. 

The bar of 70% chocolate tastes like the solid form of the drinking chocolate. It may be that the base chocolate is the same for the drinking chocolate, the truffles, and actually very simple in flavor. That works well when chocolate is the base for serving other flavors, but less interesting when wanting to really taste chocolate for its own unique qualities.  

The boutique has clean lines, polished glass, and white surfaces. The store also includes an LCD monitor flashing the current information about various products. This modern approach to the store manages to give it a slick appearance and at the same time manages to lack sophistication, subtle, and nuance.

The staff had the nearly ever present disaffected San Francisco attitude. Rather be rock stars I guess. More thoughtful, helpful, and knowledgeable than the staff at a Ghiradelli outlet, but not deeply invested in the world of chocolate.
author: Joshua W.

description:
So, walking through the Hayes Valley tonight, Christopher Elbow Chocolates has finally opened! 
Met the owner too. There really is a Christopher Elbow. He definitely has a passion for making chocolates. He was extremely helpful in explaining all the layers of flavors too.
Here are a few:
-Tanzanie (just a good, smooth and dark choc)
-Strawberry-Balsamic Caramel
-Bourbon Pecan
and my FAVORITE - Hawaiian Red Sea Salt with Macadamia!!
So good...You can taste and bite the bits of sea salt. Perfect layers of flavor bursting from every morsel.
They've got tons of drinking chocolates also. 
Can't wait to try those!
