Also, there is a seating area with newspapers and magazines, so you can just sit back, sip your chocolat chaud, munching on the delectable bites, watching the world go by.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Christopher Elbow is as good as chocolate gets.  I've been to every artisan (and non) around the city, and this is the best.  

It's beyond chocolate, it ascends to something on another tier all together.  I make special trips to Hayes Valley just to grab a few chocolates.  It says on Yelp $$$, but it's no more expensive than any other chocolatier.  I got 10 truffles and 2 large PB patties with sea salt and it was $30, not cheap, but no break the bank for SF.

Go there, I implore you.
author: Jared H.

description:
Friggin awesome chocolate!

A friend got us some of their chocolates, specifically the chocolate turtles, and they were so fantastically awesome. I almost chewed off some of my fingers that had some of the chocolate still stuck on it. The chocolate was awesome, caramel was so good, and the pecans along with sea salt on top made everything heaven.

Bottom line: Wow. I'm definitely going to drop by here to try some of their other goodies. Recchiuti, you got some strong competition in SF..
author: Jim C.

description:
OVERALL:4.5   FOOD:5   SERVICE:5   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE:4
Sunday mornings are sacred to most god-fearing Americans, and I'm no exception.  On more than one occasion, I've unearthed my Sunday best and dedicated my prime brunching hours to praising & worshiping.....CHOCOLATE.

Christopher Elbow has somehow created a space & experience that unites 2 of Girls' BFFs: chocolate & shiny!  The bright little truffles are artfully displayed in pristine cases, throwing off golden sparkles (REALLY!), specks, and swirls.  Except these pretty wares are better than any jewelry, cuz they're EDIBLE, and while they're several washingtons above Hersheys prices, they won't cost you 2 months' salary.

FAVES:
Rosemary Caramel, Caramel with Fleur de Sel, Venezuelan Spice. Drinking chocolate is Euro-style & decadently THICK...positively sinful!  Best enjoyed in the snazzy lounge area w/somebody(ies) special....

Thank you, Jesus & amen!
author: Amy K.

description: Chocolates are pretty good, but not worth the price. They are made out of state and shipped in, which was a little disappointing too.
author: Boris C.

description:
Artisanal chocolates for the soul.

The +'s:
+ Clean glass paned chocolate store that allows seating for 5-6 people that faces the street.  Great for watching the city life go by while you sip a hot chocolate and indulge in artisanal chocolates  Personal favorite is the mocha hot chocolate ($4.5) and caramel coffee ($2).
+ Chocolates come in all forms that include the bite-size, the bars and the liquid. They all satisfy those who need a chocolate fix.
+ Bathroom is also quite beautiful gorgeous. Great design.
+ Great stop for those chilly days while shopping in Hayes

The -'s:
- Wish there were more seating
- Any cookies with chocolate here? Or even pastries?
author: Yiven C.

description:
You can't even call it hot chocolate because it's too ridiciulously thick. Their name for it, Liquid Chocolate, is much more appropriate. 

Unfortunately when I went, they did not have any more roasted hazelnuts for the hazelnut liquid chocolate, so I just got the standard Cocoa Noir which was melted dark chocolate swirled together with rich and creamy milk. For $4.50, I think it's pretty worth it, because it took me and two other people almost an hour to finish it. It is that rich.

Next time I venture here, i want to try their chocolate bonbons.
author: Julia K.

description:
Like most women, I love chocolate.  And I like designs and packaging.  So, naturally, a store like Christopher Elbow is my fly paper, and I am instinctively inclined to zoom towards it.  

The interior of the store epitomizes the word yuppie.  Or posh.  Or poshie.  At any rate, once you enter the store you find a counter full of beautifully decorated pieces of chocolate, and to the left a lounge-like seating area with dimly lit cubes.  All of the chocolates, are, as expected, extremely pricey for a small box of them.  One friend said she bought some of the chocolate with pop rocks in them, so there is an interesting little pop with each bite.

I decided to indulge a little and get a cup of the drinking chocolate.  We settled in the cushy chairs and sipped, but I found my chocolate (with passionfruit) a little TOO sweet...even for me.  And that's saying a lot.  Even though the first two sips were nice, trying to drink the $4.50 worth of chocolate is not really worthwhile.  If you decide to indulge, I suggest sharing with a friend.

In a nutshell, it's a decent place to buy fancy candy if you want to impress someone (and you've used Godiva one too many times) or if you feel like sitting around and people watch through the windows in a chic atmosphere.  But as for me, I'm not sure I'll be hankering for anything from there anytime soon.

Oh yes - be sure the check out the bathroom.
author: Shay F.

description:
Where I live, we really don't have a lot of options for fine chocolate confections.  I made sure to hit several chocolate places on a recent trip to the city and Christoper Elbow Artisan Chocolate was one of the places I made sure to hit up. 

 Everything that I bought at CEAC was quite good. 

I bought a box of 16.  
- I found 9 of them to be amazing
- 4 to be good, but not something I would pay that much for again
- 3 to be not good at all. 

The star was actually the Venezuelan spiced turtle I got to eat as a snack for that day.  It was AMAZING, a wonderful balance of sweet/spicy.  Now that I would pay extra for again!
author: Jen A.

description: Wowie: So expensive, but oh so good. Chocolates are gorgeous and even more delicious than gorgeous. I had the perennial fave: the salty caramel and there were no regrets. None.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Being a  chocoholic since birth and between family, friends, co-workers over the years I must first point out that every chocolate lover will have a personal favorite and according to taste buds, that will be different from person to person.  It comes down to personal preference.  Ok, enough babble about that, lets go on to rating the chocolate!

Ever watch Spongebob Squarepants?  Ok, indulge me here just for a minute or skip over if you have no idea who Spongebob is.  

In one episode Spongebob and Patrick want to be entrepreneurs.  In their quest for this high living they decide to sell.....yes you guessed it (or saw the episode) chocolate!   One of the first customers they try to entice with a  velvety smooth chocolate bar gets a glazed looked in his eyes (not hard for a fish) and gets to screaming "CHOCOLATE!"  While trying to catch Spongebob and Patrick.

Well the point of that is, Christopher Elbow Chocolates put me in the same state of mind!  

With over 50+ years of sampling chocolate for me, CB chocolate is simply heaven and dare I say it, orgasmic?  Might as well, Spongebob sure can't say that :)

Some don't care for the exotic flavors or think that a Rosemary flavor center is not suitable for a chocolate.  Personal preference once again comes into play here.  Personally I adored every flavor with the exception being Marzipan however I always preferred Marzipan without chocolate.

The chocolates (in case you don't know) are not made with any preservatives or additives (another plus)!  So these are best consumed within a two week period.  I can't see these lasting anyone a week let alone two :)

The dark and milk chocolate is just exceptional!  A thin chocolate shell with the right amount of snap to it.  A lot of the centers are liquid which is just phenomenal to my taste buds!  I love liquid centers.  The favorites so far are: (not in order of preference)

Champagne
Vanilla Bean
Venezuelan Spiced Caramel (I could eat an entire box of these alone)
Caramel with Fleur de Sel (Can I just order a full pound of one flavor?)
Cabernet Caramel
Lavender Caramel
Rosemary Caramel
Bananas Foster (again lets order a full pound of this)!
Grand Marnier
Citrus Caramel
Yuzu

I order  these three to four times a year online in the 21 piece collection (glad there isn't a CE locally, really I could not control myself if there was).  When I order them I always get a box of them for Mom.  Mom has been a chocoholic for 88 years so I know where I inherited that trait :)

Mom and I sit and open the leaflet and decide which flavors to try first and marvel at the artistry of each piece.  Mom confesses, they are without a doubt the best she has ever had and won't even give in to buying her old time favorite, Helen Grace (no comparison of course,  it would be like comparing apples to oranges).

So Mom waits ever so patiently for the times during the year that I order her a box, Christmas is coming soon Mom :)

Price, ok.... yes very expensive!  Worth it?  To me yes they are worth it and my Mom also agrees.  Course she says I should not be spending my money on her but sure won't refuse that box of Christopher Elbow chocolates.  Every time I hand her a box her eyes light up and she asks...."Is this that Chocolate you bought me before?"

Yes Mom, there is a Santa Claus!
author: R W.

description:
Love the beautiful chocolates!  Very fun to give these to my sweet-heart!  

I had some trouble finding the place, it's a little non-descript from the street.  There was a stack of boxes in the front window that on first glance made me think the place was a work in progress.  I also wished I had been offered a sample!
author: Savanna M.

description:
I wish I could give two separate reviews. One for the chocolates and another for the hot chocolate. They would differ. 

The chocolates are a win. Their flavors span from flowers (lavender), fruits, (bananas foster), spice (chai) and spirits (champagne). They are beautifully painted, and the chocolate has a nice snap, and then melts in the mouth. 

But I did not enjoy the liquid chocolate. First, it was not very hot. It is tepid to lukewarm. This made it feel like I was drinking chocolate milk that was set on a radiator for too long. Not too good. I got the dark chocolate and expected it to be darker and richer. Also, the staff had the air of many other staff in the hayes valley area - smug, not thrilled to be there, and barely tolerant of you.
author: Matt C.

description: It's a rare occasion for me to be in this neighborhood. However, when I am, I'm definitely going to make it a point to visit this place. While I haven't had the actual chocolate, I am a HUGE FAN of the Liquid Chocolate (aka hot cocoa). They're decadent, full of unique flavor, and not overly sweet. I've had the spicy version (Venezuelan?) and the Ginger Caramel. Both were divine!
author: Joanne R.

description:
Favorite - Maple Walnut, Salted Caramel, Spiced Pear, Orange Pekoe
Pro - Beautiful hIgh quality chocolate, not too sweet, snaps.
Con - Kind of pricy ($20 for 9 pieces) and hard to find parking.


I think I'm in love.  The outside shell snaps and the inside is soft, not too sweet, and perfect.  They are so beautiful, they look like little gems.  I especially love the Maple Walnut, Salted Caramel, and Spiced Pear.  

I'll definitely go back to get some more even if it's pricy :p
author: Patara R.

description: The chocolates are handcrafted with perfection. They have seasonal chocolates beside the regular chocolate squares. I'm addicted to their (dark chocolate) fleur de sel caramel patty and peanut butter patty. I had a chance to meet Christopher Elbow himself during a tasting in the chocolate; he was humble!
author: Nicole H.

description: came in by accident and couldn't resist buying a huge box of truffles for their taste and beauty. will come back for the bars!
author: Char Y.

description:
Creamy vanilla shooters, golden flutes of passion fruit, milk chocolate coating your palette with a punch of bourbon as a front note, pure luxury in a single swig....now let's talk about the chocolate.
Exquisite drops of  chocolate, delicately hand-made, and decorated with intricate patterns corresponding with the flavor of each buttery morsel. Essence of sea salt, rosemary and russian tea, to name a few, are the most unusually satisfying flavors to meet my lips, only seducing me, inviting me to sample each and every coffee, caramel, rasberry, mint and passion fruit bundle of decadence.
author: regina k.

description: My husband and I decided to try this place after seeing a bunch of people inside sitting comfortably on what looked like comfortable couches.  The chocolates were pretty good, but their service was really lacking.  One of the girls didn't really seem to be interested in helping anyone at all and was sitting on one of the plush chairs looking really apathetic staring into space munching on a bag of popcorn.  Then, when one of the other patrons spilled a cup of water on the floor, no one went to clean it up, and he had to ask for some paper towels to wipe it up. For such a nice place, it can really do better.  Not planning on coming back.
author: Julie P.

description:
Walking back to my car after brunch, I found myself walking straight into this place without even thinking about it. The person I was with thought I had been there before, but really it was just instinct.

We each limited ourselves to 3 chocolates each. Russian Tea, Grand Marnier, Banana Curry were mine. I remember each distinctively, but the Banana Curry was my favorite.

A week later I returned with an additional person. I tried the Passion Fruit, Persian and once again - Banana Curry.

Something about the sweet rich chocolate combined with the curry spice triggered something wonderful in me.

The Persian was on par with the Banana Curry. A complexed array of spices all working together to balance the sweetness of the chocolate really made my day.

The strong sweet fruity flavors are nice, but definitely try the curry and other spices. Next time, I'm getting the Rosemary one.
author: Brad D.

description:
$10 for 4 pieces of chocolate, WTF I don't even like boxed chocolates! Okay, okay beautiful, artisan, high quality chocolate I guess I have to give you a try - even if it might be a one time thing. I pick the macademia nut thingy, little salted caramel beehive, cappuccino, and....WTF Stephen N. you want the PEAR one?! ewwwwwww, okayyy you can pick ONE...

In all seriousness, any negative feeling I had toward these high priced chocolates were completely squashed when I tasted the chocolate. Never before have I had candies that taste absolutely as beautiful as they look. I was wowed by the pear, especially. I usually hate pear flavored things as they taste particularly unnatural to me, but this little chocolate was heavenly. Each piece was fantastic and I was severely disappointed that I didn't spring for a larger sampling. Come on, try at least one!
author: Juliana C.

description:
Wow! I feel special writing about a SF-based establishment with "only" 110 reviews! 

Needing some gifts for friends, we stopped in on a stroll through Hayes Valley. Michael, the guy behind the counter, was extremely knowledgeable about the process and each different chocolate. 

The "artisinal" chocolates they claim in their name ain't just whistlin' Dixie; each piece is handmade and takes from 2 to 5 DAYS to make. They use airbrushes and silk screening to make finishes on some of the pieces. These are not terms you usually hear thrown around when talking about chocolate, kids.

I bought two pre-made gift boxes of 9 pieces ($20), which are assembled from their best sellers, or you can custom pick them yourself. But with flavors like Rosemary caramel (colored deep green and amazing-- rosemary knows how to play well sweet), lavender, Russian teacake, and strawberry balsamic, I knew I was in way over my head, so I picked up a few premade boxes.

They also sell cocoa powder and gift sets that range from 'Yugo" to "Escalade", and have an espresso machine if you like to sit a spell in a quiet cafe setting.
 
I can't recommend this place enough, when you're buying gifts for  someone, even if it's yourself!

Also, when you go in, be SURE to visit the bathroom. You'll know why when you see it.
author: Austin D.

description: AND here I thought curry was only good in food?! I know everyone comes here for the chocolate pieces which I admit are *heaven* in your mouth BUT I have to say my fav things here is the many varieties of liquid chocolate (a.k.a. hot chocolate). I've tried several and my total fav is the curry and coconut dark chocolate -- every drop is like a dance in your mouth and simply not to be missed. ;-)
author: Alma P.

description:
Oh dear god why are overpriced chocolates so awesome?!

I TOLD the man I wanted fancy chocolates for Valentine's Day - because I have learned that hinting DOES NOT work. So once we realized the price point we were dealing with I got to choose 9 pieces (for $20). 

As a tip - get anything with caramel in it - Fleur de Sal, milk caramel, whatever -- they are by far the BEST ones. Their caramel must have crack in it! 

The spicy Venezuelan is good, the passion fruit unique, the Bourbon pecan tasty, they are ALL dee-lish. BOYFRIEND, WHEN CAN I HAVE MORE?
author: Jessica L.

description:
I have one word for Christopher Elbow - rich! 

My drinking chocolate was the peanut butter/dark chocolate flavor - think of the most fantastic Hershey's Peanut Butter cup melted down and topped with homemade whipped cream. Still thinking? It's better than you can imagine. But man was it rich! It took everything I had to get through the small cup.

The other thing rich about Christopher Elbow - the prices. Each small piece of chocolate costs $2.50, definitely not cheap but they have flavors you'll never find at See's! Our drinking chocolates were $4.50 each which isn't really that bad considering the amount of love* that went into each cup. 

I'm not a choc-o-holic but I can definitely see myself coming back to Christopher Elbow from time to time to enjoy a cup of chocolatey goodness.

*No, not that kind of love...perv.
author: phil h.

description: The liquid chocolate is absolutely amazing. Hands down the best hot cocoa I have ever had. It's rich and smooth, and almost as thick as pudding. We got the peanut butter and it was just wonderful! The seating kind of stinks, though. The tables are tiny and too low, and they have uneven surfaces, so good luck balancing your full-to-the-brim hot cocoa cup on your knee. That is my only complaint, though. The liquid chocolate is so worth the crappy seating.
author: Cattie P.

description:
The first time I came here, the samples were half pieces of the Earl Grey.  Shamelessly I helped myself to several precious pieces as I contemplated what other ones to buy for a 4-pack.  Earl Grey and chocolate are a match made in heaven.  

The second time, there were no samples.  WHY WHY WHY?!

I tried the drinking chocolate though.  Just the dark chocolate with water, or Euro-style one.  I wanted to try the cool ones with spices but thought I'd go for the standard on my first go.  It was good... but it was sweeter than I thought it would be for dark chocolate, and also kind of on the thin side.  For 4.50 I expected it to blow my mind!  I'm on the fence about whether to try a more interesting drink.. or to put my money into two pieces of amazing chocolate.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Though we only tried two (the Jamaican Rum and the Russian Tea) I feel comfortable saying that these are perhaps the finest handmade chocolates I have ever tasted - and I used to sell at the chocolate counter at Neiman Marcus, back in the 90's. 
The shop is pristine and elegant, and the staff friendly and justifiably proud of their product. Kansas City, MO. Who'd-a thunk it?
author: Amy B.

description:
I wish it was my birthday and my gifts were boxes from CEC...

Curry Spiced Drinking Chocolate - AMAZING....not even close to being overpowered by curry...a cup of any of their drinking chocolates with homemade marshmallows.....sounds pretty amazing right now

Mango Passion Fruit  - not on the site, but possibly similar to [Passion Fruit: Caramel made with the tropical taste of passion fruit]

Vanilla Bean - Caramel infused with Tahitian vanilla beans

Venezuelan Dark - Ganache of 70% cacao from Venezuela

Persian - Almond marzipan with a Persian spiced ganache....saffron, clove, cardamom, cinnamon and orange blossom

Hazelnut - Not on the site either...but it was gooood.

PS. I want to work here...
author: Kelley N.

description:
Christopher Elbow, 
You had me at "Strawberry Balsamic Caramel."  Then I saw Champagne, Raspberry, Tahitian Vanilla, Bananas Foster and CABERNET CARAMEL and knew the truth.  You complete me.

Did I really spend $12 on six chocolates?  Yes, yes I did.  Have I already inhaled five of them a mere 2 hours after purchase?  Yes, yes I have.  The only one that didn't wow me was a port caramel - I knew I should've gone with the cab.  The fillings are so luscious and silky smooth, I mean wow.  The Fleur de Sel knocked my socks off further than I expected.  The boxes of chocolate look like they're filled with baubles and gems rather than chocolate, and to that end, the boutique is set up more like a high end jeweler than ye olde candy shoppe.  A bit austere for my cozy tastes, but very elegant and clean, an excellent showcase for these tiny, edible works of art.

Don't think I'm not stopping by here again on my way home tonight (and perhaps every night much to my waistline's dismay).  Unfortunately at $2 a pop, all of my Valentine sweeties will have to savor one lone morsel and know that I love them.  I leave it to the individual to decide if one small piece of beautifully designed candy is worth two whole dollars.  I'm knocking one star off since I'm not so sure of that myself.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Can the word "gorgeous" be used to describe chocolates? Perhaps. How about "luscious" or "orgasmic"? I'm guessing so, and these three words pretty much sum up what Mr. Elbow has in store for you. Actually I'm not even sure if there is a Christopher Elbow, if he's more like Robin Masters (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Masters), but his chocolate creations are heaven sent, and isn't that the important thing?

So far, I've enjoyed CE two ways. The first was by me or a friend hand-selecting a set of choolates and enjoying them at home later, after dinner. There are some pretty exotic flavors, all worth tempting your tongue with, and all delectable with a goblet of red wine.

Most recently, some friends and I enjoyed some of their sinfully rich hot chocolate right there and then: the seating here is against one wall  and it all faces out to scenic Gough Street, so you can watch cars whiz by and people coming and going from Absinthe across the street. It's a curious set up, which happily works.
author: Nish N.

description:
Goodbye Friend, HELLO Christopher Elbow! The newly opened chocolate boutique that took over the modernist home accessories store on the corner of Hayes and Gough also has a hot chocolate bar, so you can lounge in style while indulging in decadent chocolatey goodness in solid or liquid form. 

On my way to visit the DASHing bambino and his parents, I stopped in to pick up a box of these luxurious chocolates for them. I was greeted by not one, but three smiling faces behind the counter. I browsed the miniature works of art and being indecisive, I asked one of the girls for her recommendations. She helped me put together a custom set of 9 pieces, which consisted of:
Peanut Butter w/ Pop Rocks 
Russian Tea 
Lavender Caramel
Ecuador
Scotch
Venezuelan Spice
Macademia nut
Passion Fruit
Absinthe (yes, real absinthe in a pearlescent green dark chocolate shell)

The assortment of the uniquely designed pieces created a gorgeous collection, almost too pretty to eat. Of course, I couldn't leave without getting a box for myself as well. I got a box of 4 for $10. My favorites so far are the Pop Rocks (like a party in your mouth!), Macademia Nut, and Russian Tea. My mission is to try at least one of each of these exquisitely crafted bon bons.

Make sure you check the shop's hours, as they vary. On Fridays and Saturdays, they're open later until 10pm, so you can stop in after a glass of Absinthe across the street for a chocolate version of it.
author: Connie C.

description:
If you find yourself in this gorgeous chocolate shop ( which looks & feels more like a jewelery store)
go ahead and get me a 9 piece box of the following 3:

Lavender Caramel
Rosemary Caramel
Strawberry Balsamic Caramel.

Thanks in advance.
author: Karlee D.

description:
At $2+ per piece of chocolate it had better be good and with this chocolate coming from, of all places, Kansas City I had my hesitations. I just never thought of the Midwest as a haven for fine chocolate. Well, Kansas city gave me a great big "Shove it up your ass, you ignorant fool" with Christopher Elbow. 

The anticipation was sweet, since I refused to give my boyfriend the pieces I had carefully selected for us until he was in the proper light to see just how pretty the chocolates were. Yes, they are actually attractive enough that I refrained from eating them until we could share them in the proper light. No, I do not know what the hell is wrong with me, so please do not ask. 

Anyhow, after hours of carting them around, there we were, pulling them out of the bag and oohing and ahhing their intricate designs and glittery air blown sheen. Then we tried them, and 4 stars were born. 4 yummy flavorful chocolate ganache stars. 

Minus one star for the rosemary and lavender caramels not really being the best flavored caramels I have ever had, but they were awfully attractive as well so I won't knock them too much.
author: Drue C.

description:
The bathroom in this place could be on craigslist as a studio apartment. All stark white with motion-control faucet and glass-slant sink- a flash of my filthy hand and MAGIC! water. A swath of scarlet vermillion mosaic tile all around the room as if some period-soaked wall-ho circle-humped it. More artistic than the last minimalist LA show I saw- some rich aquitted murderer dude glued a bunch of zinc squares on the floor and people were supposed to like it- http://www.yelp.com/biz/ace-gallery-beverly-hills#hrid:wSB0p-yH9_tr5r1x2kBIeg

What's that you say OH THE CHOCOLATE- NOOO I'm not going to make THAT comparison- that's gross. It's just that I really had to pee when I stopped by- so the bathroom was my first impression- but I gave Ms. Elbow my order first. Candy is ALWAYS first, specially chocolates.

Lavender caramel, cherry cognac chocolates  and a dark stiffly - mmmmhmmm that's what I said- frothed cappuccino. yes I am a lover of the bloodsugar jack-up. 

Just round the corner from the pusher at the counter on the path to the studio apt / art gallery magic water room is a cool seating area. The store is in an L shape with one leg all in moderne seating simplicity: sectioned long row of smooth vinyl with intermittent tiny flat tables and lit up squares in front like oversized white gumdrops. Facing you as you sit all sugared up is a full window of Laguna Street. 

AHHH sit back in silence. Watch the chocolate-less fools rushing off to ugly bathrooms while you sit and ponder the play of light and shadow, lavender and cognac, the prism shapes and gem colors of your candy.   Especially satisfying at rush hour. Five o' clock fools just hurry, YOU get the rush.
author: Squinka C.

description:
It is to be expected that the stuff they sell at this fancy jewel store are going to be expensive.  It's at the corner of Hayes and Gough.  Location! Location! Location.  

I walk in, after my lovely haircut appointment, because I am a sucker for jewels... well, not REAL jewels, but jewel-shaped CHOCOLATES!   Chocolatiers are becoming smart... looking into the psychology of chocolate marketing: 1) find who the most avid consumers of chocolates (women); 2) find out how to market chocolates to avid consumers by looking at packaging and presentation (make chocolates look like jewels and put them in jewelry boxes, tie with fancy ribbon).

These *sosyal* establishments looked too rich for my blood, and it kinda was (2 pieces, 1-inch in diameter, for $5; 9 pcs for a dub, a small 8oz cup of hot cocoa for $4.50... wow! ang mahal!)... but I had to at least TRY IT before I knocked it.  

The chocolates are all laid out on a counter (which is probably marble of some sort to keep the chocolates intact) looking like polished JEWELS!  Oh I LOVE IT.  It's a way to this girl's heart.   They also taste gloriously wonderful and sinful at the same time.  The chocolates are mostly dark, encasing some flavored caramel.  I got 9 different ones to share with my dinner party later in the evening.

On the other side of the establishment are lounge chairs with mini counters. While the layout and design of this lounge area (and the cool bathroom sink) are nice, i think it's a waste of space, but justifies the exorbitant prices of the goods.  Okay, I'm an asshole for saying that... this feature is somewhat nice if you just want to take a small pause in your hectic, fast-paced life to enjoy the traffic in front of you, while you sip your hot cocoa (and you HAVE TO SIP IT because it is very richly sweet and hecka mad expensive to just slam it... so yeah... slow.down.turbo! sip it. just. sip it.) and nibble (savor it please) on your fancy chocolates.  They have newspaper racks on the side too.... suggesting, "hey! you may as well take a paper and relax!" says Frankie.  I thought it was quaint that there is a copy of The Onion hanging on one of the dowels. 

So far I had the strawberry balsamic one and the absinthe caramel (very "absinthe-y" flavor according to salty balls).  Sweet enjoyed the orange blossom honey caramel.  Salty popped the bananas foster in his mouth, as if it's a mere peanut m&m.  Diva yelled at him, "DAMN! you're supposed to just take a small bite first!" and savored the lavender caramel.   Oh well, he's a dude and does not know any better.  Guapo had the passion fruit caramel, because he's full of passion, ladies.  Husky  opted not to have any because she just doesn't like chocolates at all, but supposedly makes "panty-dropping" carbonara, fellas.

Call me anal-retentive, but I really scrutinize how the customer service reps handle the chocolates (edible consumer item) while also trying to package the goods and ring up the customer's wares.  They do wear those latex gloves in one hand to pick up the chocolates, but still somewhat touch the chocolates while putting it in the box.  Now, what is the point of wearing a glove in one hand when you're still going to touch the chocolate with your other naked hand?  And it's not a clean-looking naked hand either--- it looks like it has melted chocolate on the tips and nails.  One star off for that, but the service was great nevertheless.
author: Grace M.

description:
Was here over the weekend.  My sister an bro in law surprised me with a box of chocolates from here for my bDay because they know chocolate is my weakness!!  I have only tried one so far because I like to savor each piece.  I'll allow myself to only have one piece a day since I'm not in the city often and I know I'll go crazy once I run out!  

Not only are the chocolates delicious, they're just as beautiful which makes it harder for me to eat them =P

I can't wait to go back.  Also, the bathroom is very cute!
author: Shaundel F.

description: Stopped by here for my family, they love chocolate. i sampled the 70% dark chocolate, nuff said. Grabbed a box to bring home and give to the fam, but what do you know- they melted. Fail. So i threw them in the freezer which salvaged a few of them for my sis. Next time elbow chocolate, next time.
author: Imran H.

description:
I visited this place as a South Bay'er, before BF and I went to watch the Nutcracker at the SF Ballet. Now that I live 2 blocks away from this place, I can kind of joke that I moved here just so I could be within walking distance of this deliciously addictive liquid chocolate.

Came here with the BF yesterday... we shared a Chinese 5-Spice Liquid Chocolate, which contained whole milk, chocolate powder, and espresso, as far as we could see. Having just come from (and indulged in) the macaron shop next door, we passed on the chocolates... but the liquid chocolate itself was simply amazing. I want more!!!! It was rich but not too rich, and the aftertaste was just right, and didn't leave that gross sugary feeling on one's tongue. It's v. pricey at $4.50 a pop, but well worth the indulgence.

Christopher Elbow, you do chocolate so right. As a new Hayes Valley resident, I got yo card! and you'll be sure that I'll be comin' back.

P.S. The last time I was here I got the earl grey chocolate. Nom nom.
author: Cheryl F.

description:
::CHOCOLATES::
These are the type that try to be all fancy looking... and that's the big deal.  At least that is how I see it.  Didn't taste particularly exciting and I certainly tried a fair number of offerings.  I'll pass.

::HOT COCOA::
Another place that tries to administer so much chocolate power that it becomes more about the power of the chocolate than having a proper balance with the milk.  Not a fan of this method.  Still, lots of interesting flavors to try.

Had a few of the funky ones (not the 5 spice, need to try that) and they were okay.  Again, not a great balance with the milk, and flavors are interesting, but more "interesting" than tasty.  

PEPPERMINT
It's a regular one with about 5 sprinkles of peppermint on the top.  Hence, two sips later, it's just  a regular hot cocoa.  Uhhh... hello?  What are they thinking?

WHIP
They use real whip in the cocoa!  Meaning, they whip it in the shop (no can action).  Doesn't look like top quality creme... maybe it is, but it didn't appear to be.  Still, beats canned by a mile.  

TAKE HOME COCOA
This allows you to do a proper milk to cocoa ratio.  Still, wasn't terribly excited about this cocoa.  Haven't wanted to go back to buy more.

::BARS::
Had a funky bar (can't recall) that was pretty good.  Again, wasn't feeling like I wanted to go back for more.  There are a few I might pick up in the future... ?

::STAFF::
Same guy at the counter the last two times I went.  He seems like he thinks he is in morgue.
author: Dan M.

description:
The shop is a little austere for my taste but the chocolates are shiny miniature works of art.  
I bought three pieces, the praline pop rock, caramel with port and a fleur de sel turtle.  My BFF, who is doing the low carb thing, bought the praline pop rock candy bar, saying she'd eat it after said diet was over.  Which initiated the following conversation:
Friend 1:  So are you going to eat your chocolates on the way home?
Friend 2:  No, I'll just eat them tomorrow.  I don't want to eat them in front of you, since you can't eat yours now.
Friend 1:  Well, you can eat them while I drive and describe each taste in detail.  
Friend 2:  Isn't that kind of like asking someone if you can watch them masturbate?
(Thoughtful pause.)
Friend 1:  No, it's absolutely nothing like that.  
Friend 2:  You're right, I can't believe i just said that.  

When i did eat the chocolates, yes alone, they were quite good, though a tiny bit sweet for my taste.  The fleur de sel turtle was my favorite.  So, while I'm still a #1 Recchuitti fan, C. Elbow chocolates are especially beautiful and they offer a plethora of interesting flavor combinations.  Next time I'm in the neighborhood I'll try the hot chocolate....no matter who's watching.
author: Kiki R.

description:
The BEST hot chocolate I have ever had, it's pure sinful indulgence in a little cup with a cute little foam piece of artwork.  This stuff is super rich, like drinking a melted down chocolate mousse and oh so delicious.  

A definite must during the cold months - grab a cup and head down the street for a manicure at pampered girl!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Great chocolate and a kick-ass chocolate lounge!! A very large space for such tiny chocolates. Talk about decadence...check out my pictures. And don't miss the bathroom at this place either! The lime, merlot and passion fruit flavors were very unique, although decadence ain't cheap at this place!
author: Sherry R.

description:
Saw this place had finally opened while walking home from work today.

Word of warning, 'artisan' means really pretty, ridiculously expensive, and tasty but not as good as the price would have you believe.

The chocolate here is pure eye candy (literally and figuratively).  The Pieces in there are gorgeous, they almost look like little plastic replicas of chocolate pieces with the whimsical designs stamped on them and all.

Prices are very high, on the order of $2 for a 1" square of chocolate-y goodness.

Chocolate was tasty enough, but probably not up to what I was hoping for considering the price.  I guess one must always consider the cost of the LOOK of these chocolates, since they do look stunning.

Word of warning, when I went, which was the first day they were open, the attendants behind the counter didn't seem to know anything about the chocolates besides what they had read from their cheat sheets.  They could offer few to no opinions, and at those prices, I expect them to act like a fine sommelier and convert my sugar induced rantings into a proper selection.

Ah well, hopefully they'll improve as time goes by...looks like a great place to buy a Valentine's Day gift though.
author: Eric M.

description:
Go for the consistently amazing chocolates in seasonal and savory flavors.  Carmel with rosemary is a consistent favorite.

Stay for the spiced hot chocolates in the 'lounge'.

But I must ask...If this is such a high end chocolate place why do all the employees dress so shabby?
author: Natalie R.

description:
The Hayes Valley is a super eclectic neighborhood that boasts a wide range of great dining stops and specialty shops. After a lovely brunch at Absinthe, I stumbled upon Christopher Elbow's which was kiddie corner from the restaurant. This shop has been on my bookmark list for at least a year and even though it was 90 degrees out in SF and the lifespan of my chocolate would be at risk, I decided to check it out anyway. 

Chocolates are a crazy world of their own these days and it never ceases to amaze me to see what exotic flavors chocolatiers come up with next. This shop was no exception and carried an unimaginable collection of flavored caramels that included Passion Fruit, Rosemary, and Strawberry Balsamic. In addition to the above, I tried the Banana Curry chocolate. Overall, the texture of the chocolate is its strongest trait. All the pieces, as well as the bars are super smooth and have quite a luxurious texture that all chocolate should strive to have. They are the true definition of melt in your mouth. Flavor wise, I thought the variety was good, but I think I might have appreciated less of a caramel selection in the case. The caramel was delicious, but seemed to mask over the fruit/herb/spirit flavors that I wish would have come through more.
author: Christina N.

description: First off, Hayes Street is amazing!  So many great shops and restaurants.  I loved hanging out there.  I was curious and stopped in at CEAC and bought a lime chocolate - honestly, I could not taste the lime. What I really wanted was some of the drinking chocolate.   Nice place and very clean.  Based on the other reviews I should have gone in to the restroom.
author: Sparkely K.

description:
The Chinese Five Spice drinking chocolate is oh, la, la delicious. 

I think I'm going to have to work my way down their drinking chocolate menu and then start over again once I'm finished. Good thing they're close to my office!
author: Lee H.

description: Very very good ... but a little expensive
author: Gregory S.

description:
love the c E logo and slogan of  * artistic yes, starving no! * couldn't help but go in and once in, couldn't help but have chocolate. ..

+ :  beautifully, beautifully crafted chocolates with subtle silky rich textures tones and flavors. .. lovely hang out with nice large wall to wall floor to ceiling glass windows looking out onto street. .. nice and wide selection of chocolate treats and hot cocoa. .. liked the cocoa with passion fruit drink - very chocolatey with a passion fruit finish. ..

- :  a bit pricey. ..

and, wishing for another drink NOW. .. ;)
author: Y I L I W.

description:
First off, super friendly staff! The shop was empty while I sat in the lounge area and I could hear the two counter people playing I Spy ("aww, you're cheating!" "no, i'm not!" "you said it would be in the shop!" "it is!"). It was the cutest thing EVER! 

I think sometimes gourmet shops get bad raps for having snooty or indifferent customer service...but this is definitely not the case here. They were helpful and the shop girl happily answered a customer's questions about Christopher Elbow (where the main store is located, where the chocolates are made, when they opened etc.) 

I bought four chocolates:

- strawberry balsamic caramel (yummiest)
- rosemary caramel (yummy...boyfriend was partial to this one)
- absinthe caramel (too strong a flavor for me...I'm a wuss)
- peanut butter with pop rocks (makes me feel like a kid again)

I normally prefer bars to filled/flavored confections but it's always a treat to buy a few to savor every once in a while. I highly recommend the strawberry balsamic (not really a strange combination...try Bi-Rite's strawberry balsamic ice cream for more of this flavor EXPLOSION)

As for the hot chocolates ($4.50), they have 14 flavors to choose from! I decided to have the european style (dark chocolate with water) and my boyfriend chose the coconut curry (dark chocolate, coconut milk, and curry powder). 

Both were piping hot, rich and extremely creamy. (The dark chocolate flavor comes through better with water, IMO.) Though the with milk version must be even more decadent. The coconut curry tasted like a chocolate curry with a hint of spice. Very, very rich. I would like to try the hazelnut next time.

Give CE a try if you're in the neighborhood! You'll feel happy after. :)
author: Nathalie L.

description:
I know it's cliche, but when you're down in the dumps nothing makes the hurt go away like chocolate*. My close friends' two cats passed away recently and they are having a hard time. This btw is one of the reasons I'm afraid of getting pets myself, even though my apartment has a policy almost as liberal as the Zoo when it comes to keeping them.

In any case, notable Yelper Liz S. http://lizs.yelp.com has been going on a chocolate tour d'excellence lately and because of her advice when I found myself fortuitously in Hayes valley I dropped in.

Something in me changed over the past couple of years when my brain became a little more insane, and the notion of paying over two dollars for a truffle became reasonable. This temporary cocoa crazy can be the only possible explanation of why Teuscher gets so much of my greenback.

We opted to compose a 16 piece giftbox mixing in the poprocks infused pecan, wacky but intriguing strawberry balsamic and a host of other delicately painted truffles that I would never get to taste - because it was a gift.

My girlfriend and I did however get to taste, in my opinion, the litmus test of all fine chocolatiers - the champagne truffle. Overall there were a couple of problems with it - the outer shell was too dense, almost waxy. It needed to be broken down by chewing rather than the heat of your mouth. The creme interior was rich and delicious, but was made like a sloppy yet chummy bartender - too much booze. I also was unsure why the outer service was so bumpy, I like my truffles smooth and sexy. To its credit the finish and after taste was long and luxurious. 

I'll let you know later if my friends enjoyed them and it made them feel better. One other note: Elbow chocolates have been sold for a while in SF at Cocoa Bella. They are flown in from Elbow's factory/store in Kansas. Apparently the SF store, which just opened, is a test before opening other stores in the US.

*chocolate isn't the only cure, we got them some Cowgirl Creamery cheese as well. http://www.yelp.com/biz/cowgirl-creamery-artisan-cheese-san-francisco#hrid:uIJEO8_SrLjSOKItCfg7XQ

3.75 * stars
author: Brady K.

description:
I don't know how this place is able to stand the overhead in Hayes Valley & on such a prominent corner, but I'm here to give a shout-out for more people to get their lazy bottoms off their couches & go lounge at Christopher Elbow's instead. 

These chocolates are some of the prettiest chocolates I've ever seen & I've definitely been a little all over the world tasting everywhere I go. The taste is just as pretty.

Try one of each or maybe just one each time you pass by, but don't ever go by without getting something. Their version of hot chocolate is called Liquid Chocolate & you can get every flavor & combo you've ever dreamed of. Venezuelan Liquid is definitely my favorite & a hot cuppa in the lounge area with a zine or book is a perfect way to spend an hour or more.

If you know of someone that is a big fan of chocolates, you couldn't possibly go wrong with an artsy little box from Christopher Elbow's. I witnessed many customers hand-picking for their someone specials. I may go in & pretend to do the same, but really I'll be picking for me, me, me!
author: Amy D.

description: I just need to say one simple, simple thing. The passion fruit caramel is so delicious I literally did a dance when I tasted it. Gave my colleague a bite and she did the same thing. I would buy buckets of it.
author: Niki M.

description:
this was the last part of my food hunt for the day.  early that afternoon i had already had a vietnamese pork sandwhich, falafels, and chantel guillon's macaroons.  although I was super stuffed, I had to end the day with chocolates!

my favs:

-caramel pear
-passion fruit
-raspberry which had a neat jelly filling

it was $10 for 4 piece, but if you order without the box i think it's a little less per piece.  but if you're going to indulge, then go for the box!
author: C L.

description: The chocolates are designed to look like those in Cacao Sampaka, the Barcelona chocolate company. However the chocolates are NOT as good as Cacao Sampaka's. I just came back from Barcelona and I think CE chocolates were much better 2 yrs ago. The quality has gone down. Too bad.
author: Esme V.

description: The chocolates are made to look beautiful (and they do) but they taste like Sh*t. I'm all about opening myself to new flavors but tequila lime was a no go. Granted I only tasted a few and I can't judge the entire shop as a whole but the ones I taste were awful. It tasted like they put a pound of salt in the center of the tequila chocolate. The passion fruit syrup inside the chocolate was extremely sour and couldn't eat it without squinting. The hazelnut however was pretty good. Not so much the taste (ordinary) but the texture was good, it had a nice crunch. So if you absolutely have to come here (you don't there are plenty of other chocolatiers around town.. then I suggest sticking to the safe side, stay away from the candies that seem a little 'out there' because you won't win.
author: Trisha L.

description: Yuh-um!!  Went there for the first time today.  Sleek interior with little  armrest-style tables on the cushy benches for intimate seating and eating.  Lovely chocolates.  I had a Venezuelan spiced dark chocolate turtle, a bananas foster chocolate, and a strawberry balsamic caramel.  All were delicious.  Seating faces Gough, whereas people watching would be better if it faced Hayes.  Otherwise, loved it!!
author: Susie S.

description:
I am most happy to report that the overpriced, overrated, minimalist-themed home decor shoe box known as "Friend," is no more. Avast and good riddance!! 

Rushing to meet friends for happy-dinner-hour and had to "Screech!" to a halt at the chocolate oasis before me: the brand new, perfectly designed, blush-toned interior of Christopher Elbow Chocolates. Checked the watch and thought, "Sure I've got a few "milliminutes" to check out a new chocolatier."  Walked out twenty minutes later but with a peace offering: a bag of  assorted Venezuelan and Madagascar dark chocolates. Love this place.  But MAKE NO MISTAKE (thank you George Bush), this place can easily impact your cash-stash!

I don't care if this place is called Elbow Macaroni...as long as it's making the kind of chocolates I tried DAMN!
author: Johnny C.

description:
Who said math was difficult? 
rich chocolate + milk = liquid heaven
Ergo, Christopher Elbow Chocolate + milk + raspberry = liquid heaven with a hint of fruit.

Sadly, I have finally come to the day where I cannot say that all chocolate-based foods not mixed with bacon (referring to my review of Bi-rite's bacon chocolate cookie) are good. I got the raspberry hot chocolate from here as a treat for sitting through a long seminar day on a weekend. As I sit here 1.5 hours later, I still have an excessively rich and heavy feeling in my stomach. It's like the feeling of eating fried food on an empty stomach. I actually had that feeling midway through the 8 oz drink but no way was I going to toss $2.25 worth of hot chocolate (it cost $4.5 total).  The drink is so rich that I've even lost the will to eat any of the accompanying chocolate pieces I bought. CAUTION: this is not your average See's chocolate, in price or in taste. It costs a whopping $2 per piece so enter at your own wallet risk. I get a small box of these - 2 pieces for $4.5 (about) in a box - for token gifts that appear more expensive than they really are. The only caveat is that the recipient has to be able to appreciate this type of gourmet chocolate. 

Parking gets difficult toward the evening time and on Sundays (probably because the meters are free).
author: Gwen L.

description:
$2 a hit, but well worth it for a nice DARK chocolate indulgence.

Check it out now, the crowds are not there yet.
author: miriam b.

description: If you are craving for a spicy hot chocolate, this is the place to go.  The thick, creamy hot cocoa sneaks in that delicious heat as the hot cocoa coats your throat.  The sitting room is cozy but the place tend to have a line.  Be patient and you will be rewarded with the spicy Venezuelan hot chocolate.  YUM!
author: Mishee D.

description:
Usually I like my chocolate simple-- good, dark chocolate.  Spicy too.  Filled chocolates usually aren't my top choice.

BUT, i got a box here as a gift and ate the entire box in less than 12 hours.  Everything was so good. The lavender filled chocolate, the caramel fleur de sel, all i can say is WOW. There was even a banana rum something or other which was DELICIOUS.   and the strawberry balsamic was sooo good.  i wanted ice cream in all those flavors.  i savored every single bite of goodness.  I was in a nice chocolate stupor for the evening. (And in the morning..., heh heh)

These chocolates are pricey, but worth the splurge every now and then.  They are also beautifully crafted, almost didn't want to eat it.  But I got over it in a about 30 seconds.

The only chocolate I wasn't a fan of was some marzipan ganache.
author: Caroline I.

description:
Melt in your mouth delicious, but expensive chocolates. but wow wow wow - so tasty. 

Caramel Rosemary - sounds like a wacky combination, but it's excellent. Might be my favorite flavor I've tried. Super friendly and helpful staff make this an enjoyable chocolate buying experience. 

so while 9 small pieces of chocolate will cost you a little over $20 - suck it up - it's well worth it! 

I need to get back here to get more chocolate ASAP!
author: Meredith K.

description:
The best cup of cocoa I've ever had at 80% cocoa content at about $4.50/cup. Just make sure you get it in a ceramic cup, not the paper cup to go. Cups make a difference in my opinion. They also do straight up coffee drinks if you can't handle the chocolate cuz of allergies. Comfortable seating and unpretentious. The people working there are knowledgeable and patient. Check the hours before you go. Wish they were open late. 

The chocolates are beautiful-you won't want to eat them. They make an outstanding, personal gift and  you can buy a box of two for $5 mas o menos. I don't think this is expensive for a unique gift. Think of the chocolate as art. It's very sensual, a great gift for a couple.
author: Jessica S.

description: Oh my goodness, this chocolate is good.  I love the lavender caramel chocolate and the Madagascar.  I do have a gripe about the Venezuelan Spice.  I enjoy spicy/chile chocolates, the kind that actually burns my tongue but I'm just a hot freak, and this was upsetting to me.  It was just a hint.  Then again Venezuelan's are not known for having insane spicy burn your face off, running your face under the faucet, wondering when the burn will go away hot dishes.  Ugghh, just give me a fresh habanero dipped in chocolate.  Brings a tear to my eye, literally.
author: Tammie C.

description:
My man was on the verge of a low-blood-sugar-induced breakdown.  We had walked all over the city and back again only to try to get seated for dinner at 5:15pm on a Saturday and get turned away.  "Come back in 40 minutes" - we were told.  ARG. 

Must act quickly before the hunger finally overwhelms him.  Walking around the corner, I see chocolate.  Just the sort of pick-me-up he needs to tie him over until we can get dinner.  WHEW. 

We walk in and are greeted by two friendly guys who clearly know their nibs.  My man orders two pieces of the 70% (one tanzanie and the other something pretty with blue swirls on it).  I get a piece of the vanilla caramel.  For here or to go?  For here.  Oh, and a glass of water please.  No liquid chocolate today.  THANKS.

We sit down in the uberchic lounge area, savor our chocolate, watch crowds of people roll by outside.  I look over at my man.  He's smiling and enjoying the very tasty, well crafted chocolates and he says "I no longer think I'm going to die from hunger.  Of course I still need to eat dinner but I'm good for about 30 minutes." YAY!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Stopped by for a little treat on our way to the Museum of Production and Design.

The chocolates are absolutely flawless, physically.  They are absolutely beautiful.  I only wish I could try each one to see how they taste!  I tried the passionfruit caramel, and it was delicious, with a real passionfruit tang.

Though delicious, the chocolate didn't blow me away, so four stars instead of five.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
The chocolate chocolates are very pretty to look at, but I always go for the beverages, which are always interesting and yummy.  The place has a hip, modern ambiance, and is never very full so it's a great place to relax with friends.  There's usually only one employee working so it tends to be a little bit of a wait for each drink.

Give it a try!  You'll leave feeling satisfied and classy.
author: Jimmy V.

description:
I've learned about Christopher Elbow chocolates at my very favorite chocolate shop -www.cocoabella.com .  Christopher Elbow chocolate shop is now my 2nd favorite.  

After a lovely day BBQ'n at the park.  Friends and I visited the Chris Elbow store for some tasty chocolates and espresso.  All of my friends were truly impressed and a few of them never had quality chocolate before--so their eyes lit up and they had huge grins on:

My personal favorites here: 
--Vanilla Caramel - delish
--Macadamia praline - delicious, gritty goodness with nuts
--Champagne -- does it get any better than this? Amazingly good

Love love love the seating area!!!  If you haven't been here yet check it out.
We had friendly service too.. Thanks :)
author: Bonnie D.

description: This is where I go when I need to give someone the most special gift of chocolates available.  The best, the absolute best chocolates in San Francisco.  Perfect for Valentine's Day, for birthdays that end in an '0' or a '5,' for extreme gratitude ... I recommend this above all other chocolatiers in SF.
author: Joe W.

description: Chocolates are amazing. They offered a sample when we came in (and there were four of us). That was nice. Service could be friendlier and more sincere - seemed a bit robotic.
author: Marc P.

description:
Smooth concoctions that heighten your senses with their presentation, hit you with a burst of luxurious infused creaminess, and then sink away like a rock in the pond. True chocolate transcendence should linger and skip across the surface of your palette like an expertly chucked stone. 

These are enjoyable, but ultimately heavier on style than substance. High-end food in any category is about precision harmony, about dialing in that 1% wherein lies an order of magnitude leap in experience. American chefs supplement lack of mastery with its superficial trappings, like presentation and price. At least we've graduated from quantity over quality? The Europeans still have us beat.

Extra star just because SF needs an evening-hours place to grab something sweet and warm and converse sans alcohol. Not sure how the space will work though; it's a little antiseptic modern, which I think (hope?) is a bit offputting to Hayes locals, and hard to access if you're not already there. I do wish them good luck though, as a chocoholic, and will try to frequent if they can keep the selections interesting.
author: Tom L.

description:
Melty, creamy, beautiful, and tasty.

My favorites:

- Hazelnut patty (it's huge, crispy and light, tastes like a healthy Ferrero Rocher but in patty form - seriously)
- Macadamia Praline (yum)
- A dark chocolate that I can't remember the name and can't find it online, but it's the 60% dark (smooth and rich)

Interesting

- Caramel passionfruit (fruity caramel, not cloyingly sweet)
- Banana curry (chocolate with a hint of Indian spice)
author: Katherine P.

description:
I don't have too much opinion about their chocolate. But the interior makes you feel like u r in Milan or Stockholm....
I donno why....
author: Zoe C.

description:
Mmm..chocolate. I LOVE chocolate. This place is has to be heaven! Those little chocolates work me into a hot frenzy!! Just one bite and I'm ready..

Ok. I adore this place. I have decided that these little treasures will replace sex- at least for awhile. Try the macadamia praline and the persian chocolate. I can still remember the first bite..mmm. If you have time, sit your pretty little self in the lounge. So sexy and sleek, watching the world go by as you take a bite of your candies. You'll be the envy of everyone passing by..

I think that they should open the lounge up at night. It would be perfect to have some chocolates and champange there. Any thoughts?
author: First C.

description: The chocolate here is divine!  I love every morsel that crosses my lips, the darker the chocolate the better.  The hot chocolate is a real treasure, thick and packed with flavor. I take mine European style with water, and no one makes a better cup than Andrew.  I always try to stop in when he is working because he always makes mine just right.  There is a consistency to his creations that is comforting, and he is always really wonderful with superior customer service.  My boyfriend and I both think he is tops! He keeps us coming back for more.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Oh, my.... 

I decided to take the 21 bus home today and it dropped me off RIGHT ACROSS the street from Christopher Elbow Chocolates... I tried to walk past the store, but very soon I found myself standing inside the store staring wide eyed at all the BOOTYFUL pieces of chocolate.

OK, yes it's expensive, but honestly these are some delicious, if not beautiful chocolate pieces here! 

Highly recommended if you're looking for a special treat for yourself, or someone else. :)
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Coconut Curry Hot Cocoa? Spicy Hot Cocoa? Chocolate and comfy seating? Immaculate bathroom with interesting sink?

Where has this place been. A great place to relax and have a sober conversation with your friends - and when was the last time you did that?
author: Katherine B.

description: I appreciate nice chocolate, but I don't like it super bitter as many high-end chocolates seem to be. I had a pecan caramel truffle & a raspberry chocolate. Both rich and flavorful without being overly sweet or bitter. And I also love the decor of the store.
author: Lauren S.

description:
No Mama See's here.  Chocolates are great, but fetishistic service with respect to the lengthy transfer process from counter (to tray to other tray to scale to box) to bag is enough to drive the Jonesing types to hysterics.  

No mistake, this is so expensive you do *NOT* want to gorge on these.  But then again I think Mr. Elbow does the world a favor by slowing it down and easing us back into a leisurely MO.  There is some fine craftmanship here and the subtle inflections of flavor and texture on the palette deserve no less than reflective consumption.

Now when you walk in if you are nervous and end up being intimidated by what you see or just have sticker shock, then buy a $4-5 pre-made Pop Rocks chocolate bar, head round the corner to Blue Bottle Coffee for an espresso, then hit the Octavia park and bask in the sun with your li'l treasures.  You'll understand.
author: Jim W.

description:
I was trying to find the perfect birthday gift for my ultra cute Korean girlfriend and I was fortunate to stumble upon this charming chocolate shop.

I bought the 16 piece box set of really nicely designed chocolates that I knew she would like.  Very helpful staff too!  I don't know how the chocolate tastes and I'm a huge critic on chocolate, so I'm giving 4 starshines for now...
author: Keika L.

description:
I have stopped by Christopher Elbow on several occasions for little gifts or to satisfy a momentary craving - this is, of course, after waiting eight months for the construction to clear out and the chocolates to arrive! Some of the ganaches really stand out in my mind and have kept me coming back for more... passion fruit with white chocolate, Russian black tea with dark chocolate and the rosemary caramel.  I've also tried (against what I thought was my better judgment -- some things just aren't for drinking??) the curry/coconut flavored cocoa and it was incredibly rich, smoky and highly enjoyable.  

I'm officially drooling. Salivating, really. Awkward... 

I don't know why people are always saying these hand crafted darlings are too good looking to eat. I want to eat them so much more cause they look so good...  some actually sparkle like jewels.  Sweet tart necklaces have met their match in the candy-jewelry market.  

C/E simply needs to offer free samples to customers, or offer a discounted price on sample pieces.  It's hard to choose what to buy when they all look so good, but you haven't a clue what is waiting for you inside.
author: Stanley E.

description:
So when I walked into this chocolatier's shop, I was feeling distinctly cynical and cheap.  So over the $7 single origin bars with a hint of secret Venezuelan spice.  Not feeling the "drinking chocolate."  Skeptical of the undeniably gorgeous truffles and caramels artfully arranged in the pristine glass case in front of me.  "Yet another artisan chocolatier charging $2 for a one-inch square of rosemary infused caramel?" I wanted to say.  

But despite my worst instincts (and clearly I was unusually crankypants to be unmoved by chocolate) I was won over.  First of all, the two guys -- bearded, hip, and a little earnest -- were not only friendly and eager to make suggestions, they really knew their chocolate.  Second, the chocolate was really, really good.  By the time I left, I'd tried a venezuelan chocolate truffle (lightly spiced, with a lingering slight smoky burn), some insanely delicate and subtly moving tea infused thing, and an absolutely amazing chocolate turtle dusted with salt.  Amazing.  I went from being a hater to being a winner.  I bought the $32 assortment and was scarcely deterred by the fact that I couldn't select my own chocolate for the box.  "We select the chocolates and assemble these each morning," said my bearded NBF.  "You picked out the chocolates?" I asked.  "I totally trust you.  I'll take it."

The one slight (slight!) disappointment was the drinking chocolate.  Having just returned from Paris where I had savored the absinthe of hot chocolates, this was a little bit thin and forgettable.  But still delicious.  I will be back, this time for the $7 chocolate bar.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
Now what starts with the letter C?
CHOCOLATE starts with C!
Let's think of other things that starts with C
Mmm. I dunno.
Oh, who cares about the other things?

C is for CHOCOLATE, that's good enough for me!
C is for CHOCOLATE, that's good enough for me!
C is for CHOCOLATE, that's good enough for me!

Not just any chocolates, but beautiful artisan chocolates with bursting flavors like bourbon pecan, Tahitian vanilla bean, orange blossom honey, Venezuelan spice, and Russian tea. Mouth-gasm! I can not wait for this store to open late fall in the now defunct Friends store on the corner of Hayes and Gough, nestled between the Azalea expansion.
author: Cathy H.

description: The best kind of deliciousness you can imagine... Exquisitely delicious and little pieces of artwork to look at. Pricey, yes - very much so - but a good gift to someone special or yourself.
author: Julie T.

description:
You know that very personal feeling when you are dying for a cup of coffee and the person running the register is a trainee and needs to call the manager for a 5 cent adjustment to someone else's transaction - but the manager is busy frothing milk so the entire place goes into a caffeine withdrawal slo-mo?  

twas the feeling at mr. elbow's artisan chocolate emporium last sunday.

the liquid spicy Venezuelan chocolate was spectacular;  however, the artisans behind the counter appeared to be on quaaludes.
author: david b.

description:
a beautiful chocolate boutique.

guy helped us out and gave us good pointers on what to get.
really beautiful & vibrant looking pieces.
they also taste great. 
really sophisticated & unique combination of flavors.

this is a great place to get a gift for a boss or gf or to the folks.
the packaging & pieces are so delightful and attractive.
will "wow" anyone you give them to for sure.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Aren't we as lucky as Kansas City, Missouri to have the other location of Christopher Elbow Chocolates?

Some of the pieces look like Rich Art.
Some of the pieces look like original designs.
Some of the pieces look radioactive :P

The taste is explosive :)
author: dj z.

description: The hot chocolate is delicious, and so are the truffles! I just wish they would be open later for the post-theater group.
author: Jen K.

description: I went into Christopher Elbow tonight and not only did I taste the best hazelnut chocolate, drank the best hot chocolate, but I got treated with such care by the two amazing women behind the counter.  Really, I would go in there just for that. You are the best.
author: Carin m.

description: Since our car was parked in front of this place, I had to go in to check it out, dragging my boyfriend in behind me.  The fancy chocolates looked so amazing under the glass case and I didn't want to just look, I wanted to taste dammit!  The guy in front of me picked out four that were put in a pretty little box with a bow and was charged ten dollars.  So I thought I'd do the same so I picked out four, Passion Fruit, Bananas Foster, Lime and Cabernet Caramel.  I was only charged eight dollars because I opted for a cellophane bag instead of a fancy box.  The Passion Fruit was my favorite, white chocolate painted pink with a soft-liquidy center.  I loved the lime as well - more of a solid yet decadent chocolate with a hint of lime after it's been in your mouth after a few moments - what a nice surpise because I expected to tase lime and it came after all, like a drink that hits you after.  The others were good but I ate them too fast (in the theater) because the show was about to start so I didn't savor them.  I have to go back to this place for another chocolate fix or order some on the internet.  They make great gifts so if you're looking for that special something and your sweetie likes good chocolate, look no further, this is it.
author: Ruthie V.

description: I passed by this lovely chocolate store on a whim. I'm attracted to chocolate by nature and despite the price, I bought a box of 9 pieces to try. The chocolate are very pretty and taste great! They have hot chocolates but I didn't try it. I know Cocoabella sells Christopher Elbow chocolate as well so if Hayes is a bit out of your way, hit Westfield mall
author: Shirley Y.

description:
A great addition to Hayes Valley.

At first it looked like a high-end jewelry store -- big, airy and with everything behind glass. 

They have a lot of truffles that I haven't seen before; some work, some don't. Loved the Vietnamese cinnamon; the bananas foster, not so much.

Off to the side, there's a lounge area which looks more like a club.
author: Rocky A.

description:
With the corner location and the fancy display cases, this chocolatier looks like a jewelry store. With the lacquered tops and fine detailing, the chocolates look like polished stones. The only problem is that the chocolates cost two months salary. OK, they're two dollars a piece, but still, this is pricey stuff.

The flavors tend towards the exotic, like Recchutti. There's a bit more emphasis on presentation instead of flavor though. Christopher Elbow also has a focus on hot chocolate, with several different styles available in a small, concentrated shot. The salted caramel that I tried was sweeter than I expected, but very tasty.

The lounge area to the left of the counters is very chic. It wouldn't be out of place in a nightclub and is nice for a rest stop if you've been shopping in Hayes Valley for a while.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I covet exquisite things, experiences, meals and nibbles. Having driven by Christopher Elbow for what seemed like an eternity, and wanting to check it out, I finally made it in here (yes, finally made it somewhere seems to be the story of my life these days: too busy, even for Yelp reviews!).

The little boy and I wandered in here after dinner at Absinthe last week....in search of something sweet to nibble on as well as a birthday gift for our next stop that evening: a friend's birthday party. 

I was enthralled by the beautiful selection of chocolates, and loving our host who encouraged us to sample away. A truly important thing to do since we were tasting and selecting, and our "server" was hand assembling a box of 30 exquisite chocolates for the birthday girl.  In addition to being completely gracious, our server wrapped the box of chocolates, ribbon, bow and all. Perfect for the party, we surmised. Who knew Kansas City was so good at chocolate and had such panache? Thank you Christopher Elbow, I'll be back.
author: Suepattra M.

description:
my mouth is full of chocolates therefore i can't complain! 
seriously, nothing bad, its all good, i love elbow's chocolates.
those tiny pieces of heaven are meant to be looked at. so start by biting slowly, a bit a time, let the chocolate and flavor hit your tastebud.. voila, heaven! 
wish i tried the hot chocolate drinks.. i heard it was heavy.. so i'm still thinking about it.
author: Jennifer I.

description: I decided that April would be a no coffee/wheat/dairy/egg month.  It's been going well, but all of my cravings have transferred to sugar.  And, I think that's okay.  Thank goodness for Christopher Elbow.  Coconut Milk+curry+high quality chocolate+not one but two marshmallows=my April fix.
author: Sara R.

description: I'm shocked how much people love this place. A friend gave us a box of chocolate and they were all too sweet and mostly tasted horrible. Definitely not worth the price but if you want to gift fancy looking chocolate, pay a lot and don't care how they taste, this place could be for you.
author: Lo F.

description:
Nice modern decor, but not so warm and inviting. The seating arrangements seem more like a club than a cafe to sit and read the paper. 

Their dark chocolate hot cocoa was certainly thick and made of a rich chocolate and served in china if not for take out. It's the second best I've had in the city behind Cocoa Bella's in the downtown mall and 10x more chocolaty than the watery hot cocoa down the street at Citizen Cake. 

Can't say much about the chocolates though. Not a fan of that stuff in general.
author: David G.

description: I was disappointed to find out that this is not a native SF company, but one taste of the chocolates and I didn't care anymore. The storefront is a bit pretentious, but the chocolates speak for themselves.
author: K. C.

description: When chocolate is art it becomes much more expensive.  It may taste better than your average chocolates, but it is still way out of my price range and can only be considered once in a blue moon.  I like that it came with a guidebook of sorts, because I forgot which selections I made almost as soon as I made them.  The Hot chocolate was really rich and decadent, but pricey.  In fact the best advice I can give is to spend your money blindly and give all your chocolates away to friends as fast as possible.  Once they have all been eaten or given away the old "out of sight, out of mind" trick will not remind you constantly about how you are now broke from buying chocolate, no matter how delicious.
author: Kenneth H.

description: The best Hot Chocolate in the city. I tried the the Venezuelan spice and it was perfect!
author: Chris D.

description:
Chocolate lovers UNITE!  This place amazes me every time I step foot inside.  As soon as you walk in the door, you're greeted with a friendly smile and happy-go-lucky attitude by ANY of the crew here.  They are VERY helpful in giving you a suggestion if you're not quite sure what to place in your 16-piece tasting.  Ask for their favorites and you might be surprised to find that it soon becomes yours too!

FYI:  The chocolates you find here as "tasters" are bitter, so be forewarned.  If you have a definite sweet tooth, be sure to take a gander at their chocolate bars (my favorite is the pop-rock version) or drink a hot cup of coco.  :P
author: Shane P.

description:
My favorite one is the Caramel with Fleur de Sel.

The other ones are too fancy for me. They are about $2 a piece. Expensive. But they are all so pretty and colorful.

The employees are nice. The box is nice too.

I haven't tried the chocolate bars or their hot chocolate.

i don't like chocolate... but this is the place to take my boss :)

somehow, the more power you have at a company, the more you love chocolate? sucks for me (the i-don't-love-chocolate-person).

apparently kansas city has the originator, christoper elbow, who probably puts lots of elbow greese into his chocolates. 

they were good, but i don't like chocolate so that's like saying i think tampax is better than playtex.. as a man.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Damn impressive!  Yeah, it's two bucks for a piece of yummy goodness, but it is worth every cent.  And, they make it look like art work, too!

Try the Rosemary Caramel and the 100% Venezuelan!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
creamy hot chocolate (american style) and a view of Gough on a semi-sunny day. Just what this mama required to recharge. lovely, lovely.

four spatulas
author: MaMa Spatula H.

description: Yes a place for hot chocolate! I'm glad I finally got a chance to come here and I was not disappointed! I ordered the 85% dark hot chocolate and it was so goooooood. I would not recommend it if you don't like dark chocolate. It could be a little bitter, but I like it. I had a sample of a peice of their chocolate with caramel and nuts. I'll be back to try their hot chocolate noir!
author: Thu L.

description:
I love the chocolates I've tried here.  I dropped mega hints to my husband hoping he'd get me chocolates here for V-day.  
Good, strong chocolate flavor, and lovely texture.
My only complaint is that even though there seemed to be about 6 people behind the counter, and 2 customers in the store, the people behind the counter just kind of gazed at the ceiling as if they didn't know what they should be doing.  YOU SHOULD BE SELLING ME CHOCOLATE, that's what you should be doing.
As for the yelpers who complained that the chocolate eating experience didn't last that long; it's a chocolate.  It's small.  It's NEVER going to last that long unless you take tiny bites.
author: Michelle A.

description:
I was first introduced to these chocolates at the SF International Chocolate Salon at Fort Mason. They had several samples available and the one that stood out was the chocolate bar No2 Dark Spice. At first taste, it is smooth dark chocolate and then an unexpected burst of spice strikes the taste buds. This bar had the right amount of spice. If you like spicy, one the reps also recommended a Venezuelan Spiced Drinking Chocolate.  They were also selling their truffles at $2 a piece (which was a deal). I had a chance to try coffee caramel, lavender caramel, and Russian tea truffles. It was good. Chocolate was smooth and the flavor was good. I should have bought more at the time of this event. 

I pass the store almost everyday on my way home but haven't gone in. From the window, I can see that the shop looks very organized with the specialty items on the side and the truffles lined up nicely behind the glass casing. It's located on a very busy street and parking can be hard to find at peak commute hours.
author: Candace F.

description:
Private event Sunday 7/27/08

What a spectacular space for hosting a small private event.  I worked with store associate Bryan a few weeks ago to plan a party for 18 friends, featuring artisan chocolates from the store.  We provided our own adult beverages, and the store provided the Perrier and had the space set up quite nicely for the event.  Two associates were working after hours to ensure that all of the guests were treated graciously and enjoying the event.  Four or five from the event purchased chocolates to take home or for gifts.  I passionately recommend Christopher Elbow Chocolates to anyone considering a small event that has a touch of class and extra special treatment from the store associates.  We're looking forward to our next venue there.
author: Eric S.

description:
We went here for the pairing event with Moonlight Brewery.

Damn.
These are the best chocolates ever! I would love to buy out the store. They also have lots of choices for non dark chocolate lovers. LOTS of choices. Everything here is made from all natural ingredients, no preservatives. and you can tell. Also I hear the hot chocolate is TO die for.

I wanted to try at least HALF of the chocolates (basically all of them that weren't mainly dark chocolate, lol). Sadly I couldn't. My one criticism, is that because everything is mostly hand-crafted, they are expensive. Now, don't get me wrong, it's worth it. I just don't have the funds to try very many. (If i could afford it, I'd be in here every day, regardless of the hella drive from North Beach)

I would say definitely check it out at least once, if you're a native. Definitely bring your tourist friends and family.
And if you ARE a tourist and you visit Hayes Valley and don't stop in here, even if its just to stare at the gorgeous pieces of artwork called chocolate, it's a travesty.
