author: Krista H.

description:
I am definitely not a chocolate connoisseur and nor are my friends.  We stopped by here after having brunch because the store looked so cute.

We walked in, amazed by all the different types of chocolate.  They all looked so pretty that we didn't even want to eat them.  Shocked at the price (as I wrote earlier that we aren't connoisseurs), we decided to split two pieces of chocolate.  We were discussing amongst ourselves which ones we wanted to have, and talked to the staff.  The guy that served us obviously knew that we didn't know much about chocolates so he informed us about the different types. He was so knowledgeable that my friend asked if he went to culinary school.  But he just responded that he was a fat guy who loved chocolate.  He wasn't fat, but he did know his chocolate.  

We ended up with the banana foster and the raspberry square.  A little bite was enough chocolate for us because it was so rich and flavorful.  The raspberry one was the winner of the two.  I am glad that we found that place so that I can ask my friend to bring some chocolates down when she visits me in LA from SF.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Just like good wine, I really enjoy really good chocolate.  The outside of the store looks really interesting- and inviting.  The interior is minimalist and chic, and even has a little sitting area where you can enjoy your dessert. 

The chocolates are beautiful, and neatly arranged.  They had some interesting choices, such as a caramel with strawberry balsamic chocolate and dark milk chocolate.  I had the 80% dark chocolate, which was delightful.  We also had the Liquid Chocolate, which was super decadent, creamy, and rich.  Good to share, as it's so thick and filling.  

Beautiful chocolates, mini works of art, really.  These make great gifts, as the chocolates are quite unique looking.  Many have "painted" on designs and patterns.  Really, something for every chocolate lover here.
author: Sarah F.

description: Quite good. The texture and flavor of the chocolate is what one would expect from fine chocolate. With many flavors it is more a matter of taste then anything. While not the best chocolate I have had it is very good.
author: Marcus F.

description:
I think they have something for any palate. Some flavors are very accessible, some are challenging but worth it to explore (absinthe, for example).

Above and beyond anything else, you have to try the turtles, esp. the Venezuelan Spice. As a piece of candy, this is second only to the Sospiri (Italian Marzipan) that Miette carries right around the corner (my humble opinion).

Having worked for a chocolate shop before (in Mill Valley) I just have to say: if you like good chocolate, you have to pay for it. If you're going to gripe about price, don't bother with anything but Hershey's -- its all you deserve. ;-)
author: Ryan F.

description:
Most artisan chocolates look the same, beautiful and artistic, but when you eat them side by side, that's when you notice the big difference between Christoph Elbow's chocolate and all the others.  Here are the things that sets his chocolate apart from the rest;

1) When you bite into the chocolate, the shell does not crack into small pieces and separate from the fillings inside 
2) Many artisan chocolates tastes sickly sweet (probably from the corn syrup).  Christopher elbow's chocolates tastes sweet without that artificial sweet taste.  
3) The pleasant taste of chocolate lingers long after you swallowed the last piece.
4) His caramel is superb! Take a bite of his caramel filled chocolate and you will know what I'm talking about.
5) This sounds silly, but his chocolates tastes like chocolate.  Compare his chocolate side by side with other artisan chocolate, and you will know what "quality chocolate" means.

I also love his hot chocolate.  I have yet to find a better hot chocolate place in the city.  The only thing I'm not crazy about is their coffee (cappuccino, latte, etc.)  I would go to Blue Bottle Coffee round the corner for that.  But then remember, this is a chocolate store.
author: Mtk T.

description: Been a customer since they first opened. I drink the Cocoa Noir every morning for breakfast.
author: Peter C.

description:
I work down the street and have passed by Christopher Elbow so many times that I finally went in today.  What a delight! I love dark chocolate and I absolutely loved the Venezuelan Dark, the only one I tried.

I will say that I am intrigued by the drinking chocolate menu and although this place is the bomb, I now have to resort to having stronger willpower and abstain myself from this exquisite chocolate perfection heaven store/lounge so I don't see myself regretting its discovery....

All natural ingredients - no artificial preservatives are definitely a delight. Venezuelan single origin chocolate is a popular pick of this Artisanal Chocolate boutique/lounge.

A cute gathering place for your chocolate loving friends before heading out to do some retail damage in Hayes Valley.
author: Ceci S.

description: Uniquely perfect flavor combining that will knock your socks off + artistic and beautiful design...Bite size and decadent...Worth every single calorie of goodness! If you are not in SF or Kansas City...Order online. They are worth it!
author: Rachel M.

description: A friend of mine, who happens to be super hip, gave me some these chocolates for my birthday. When I opened the box, I was worried that I couldn't actually eat them because they were so beautiful. They looked like little pieces of art, that was coated in a light glossy coating. I decided to just do it and have no fear. The tastes were fantastic, lavender, bananas, heaven! If i ever need to get anyone chocolates from now on, it's from this place!
author: Erik U.

description: They have really great chocolate! I bought a few different kind of chocolates home and i just cannot wait finishing them in one minute.. They are so good. And drinking their signature hot chocolate and chatting with friend in the sunshine afternoon was so much enjoyable. Cannt wait visit there next time!
author: Kyle S.

description: I have never been a fan of chocolates... but I am a fan of Christopher Elbow!  If you're unsure about truffles, this place will make you a believer.
author: Taryn S.

description:
Next time, reason may dictate skiping brunch (safe for caffeination) and beeline to this chocolate spot for sunday pleasure. One requires belt bandwidth to experience THE experience which is Christopher Elbow chocolate.
Luckily, I seemed to be wearing a dress, so going beyond the beltline was available. We went for a sampling; agreed Chai was the weakest of our selections (something too much like Nann and Curry to be dessert), found the darkest choc to be simply devine (if i fell to the floor in convulsive rhapsody, he might eat the remainder expeditiously before calling 911..) The Earl Grey was very nice, though more suited to a winter rainstorm in faraway cabin than sunshine lightness which was Nov 1, 09. I regret that I don't recall the fourth flavor he'd chosen as I was busy dreaming forward--Yuzu! Salted Carmel! Raspberry! As this spot is dangerously few blocks from home of chez lui, a moment of logical regroup will be needed to offset weakness (parameters like--" have you at least been to the gym since last visit?" and other assorted hoops), though I sheepishly predict I may become a holiday season regular...  Since Who doesn't re-invite the wide-eyed lass toting artisan chocolate and wearing a potato sack which tucks away her season of grandeur?
author: Rachel S.

description: These chocolates are works of art. You almost feel like framing instead of eating them. Their hot chocolate is way really rich and hard to consume in full. The one gripe about this place is that they have n space for their boxes, which you often find monopolizing a lot of the space in the store...just does not work :(
author: Vivek N.

description: It's been a long time in the works, but Christopher Elbow is finally open for business.  I decided to deviate from my regular Blue Bottle trek and picked up a thick and "dark as sin" Mocha as well as a good variety of chocolates to keep my dentist busy.  The quality of the chocolates are almost in line with Rechutti's, but I love the fact that you can grab a warm drink, chocolates and then chill in their lounge area.  Although Christopher Elbow isn't a local company, they are a welcome addition to Hayes in my opinion.
author: Jason A.

description: Umm honestly? THE BEST HOT COCOA I'VE HAD IN MY LIFE. Read about this gem in a "The Top 3 Hot Cocoas in SF" article, and it definitely deserved its spot on that list! It's more of a chocolate shop/boutique (duh, it's a Chocolatier--but thought I'd throw that out there). They have a long L shaped booth separated by cubes that serve as both arm rests and side tables, but it has a more of a modern rather than cozy feel. Although I personally prefer a cozier atmosphere, the layout of the place was very "sexy" (yes, sexy chocolate), trendy, and cool. Definitely a unique experience. The chocolates themselves are adorable (e.g., they had pumpkin flavored and SHAPED chocolates), and the PEANUT BUTTER HOT COCOA I had was AMAZEballs. CREAMY, RICH, THICK hot cocoa with a large square marshmallow floating atop. lskdfjskdf. Drooling on my keyboard. They also had other interesting flavors like the Venezuelan Chocolate (if you don't like mixing spicy w/sweet, I wouldn't recommend it. But I tried a sip of my friends and enjoyed it). Pretty pricey for hot cocoa at $4.50/cup, but I'd highly recommend this place if you want a special cup of cocoa. =)
author: Diane G.

description:
Christopher Elbow is a bad chocolatier with enough investment to dawn the disguise of a good chocolatier to people who don't know any better.

The strawberry balsamic was poorly tempered and showed signs of weeping, which is just terrible when purchased in shop. The flavor was overly acidic (cheap balsamic) with almost no depth of flavor.

The banana foster tasted like a bad version (if possible) of one of those radioactive looking, styrofoam feeling Brach's circus peanut candies. The finish was of cheap, harsh rum.

The rosemary was over-extracted and just tasted bitter, bitter, bitter. At this point I started wondering, "why all the caramel, because it is cheaper than ganache?"

I tried several other pieces as well, that peanut butter pop rocks thing, just a bad version of Oriol Balaguer's hazelnut pop rocks thing, not the least bit creative or avant garde. The rest were just technically poor, bad temper, seams on the base, cracks, weeping, all around garbage.

For the same money in San Fran, to to Richart.
author: Catch X.

description: This is an expensive way to get your chocolate fix, but it's unique enough that it's arguably worth the price.  There's a wide variety of chocolate drops in appealing and bizarre flavors.  I particularly liked the Venezuelan-spiced chocolate turtle.  Not a lot of seating in the store, but it shouldn't be a problem to go as long as you don't end up with an expensive chocolate mess melted in your pocket.
author: Dano W.

description:
as we were trying to find some snack to hold us over for the symphony, we walked by this simply & elegantly designed shop, that looked more like a jewlery/art shop than a food place. 
then i saw the big menu board of hot chocolate - regular, dark, raspberry, chinese 5-spice, curry...
and my feet stopped right on the spot as i drooled and my brain insisted that i MUST stop in there.

so stop we did... 

---------------------------------------------

i've been to this shop twice, and probably tasted half the chocolates and 3 different flavors of their hot chocolate.. i love this little chocolatier... love!
the hot chocolate is SINFULLY RICH  - i can barely finish the little cup they serve it in. liquid chocolate in its finest... i've had regular their cocoa noir, which impressed me to no end. i've also tried some of my friend's dark drinking chocolate, which has an intense and slightly bitter flavor from the VERY dark chocolate... i like dark chocolate, but you have to be absolutely, unequivocally love the darkest of dark chocolate to truly appreciate this. i've also tried the raspberry drinking chocolate, which i also love - the fruity flavor cuts a bit of the richness of chocolate...

i've bought their hot chocolate mix too and it is equally heavenly when made in the comforts of my own home... worth the expensive price they charge. I've made them and compared side by side with William Sonoma's fancy drinking chocolate, and hands down no competition, Christopher Elbow's hot chocolate wins, and warms my heart.

---------------------------------------------

the pieces of chocolates themselves are small - a perfect mouthful in my opinion. you can taste all the combination of ingredients in it. i've had

the Banana Curry
the Yuzu
the Pineapple
the Strawberry-Balsamic Caramel
the Venezuelan Spice
the Vanilla Bean. 

By the staff's recommendation, i've also had the Tanzanie and Venezuelan Dark side by side as comparison... they were both dark chocolates, but the origin really does affect the taste - the Venezuelan Dark is smooth, slightly toasty flavor, the Tanzanie is very fruity and a more raw edgy flavor.

they also have comfy leather seating on the side of the store for hanging out when you enjoy the hot chocolate - excellent for people watching as the traffic crosses in front of you in Hayes Valley. they never hurry to get you out of there or pressure you to buy anything - bonus points!

i am glad to be living 50+ miles away from this place or else i'd be a big fat cow having this much chocolate... this place is such a treat, and it's made it on my list of 'must visit' when friends come into town. did i mention i absolutely love this place? :)

 "you had me at chocolate..."
author: amy c.

description:
I received the 9 piece 'collection' as a Christmas gift. Thank you Sera A! It was a very thoughtful gift as I do love chocolate. 

Aesthetically, the chocolate is beautiful. The pieces are impossibly smooth and shiny and decorated with intricate patterns. You can tell a lot of thought goes into each type and I was very impressed. 

And then I tasted a piece.....SOUR. The chocolate was sour. I hate hate hate sour chocolate. I tried other pieces and 6 of the 9 had a distinct sour taste in the chocolate. It was very disappointing. 

With the fillings, Christopher Elbow will definitely give you flavors you have never experienced in chocolate before. Rosemary, bananas foster, cabernet, are just some of the flavors encapsulated in these chocolates. I will give them credit; the flavors did accurately match their descriptions (i.e. the bananas foster flavor really did taste like bananas foster.) So while flavor fidelity is nice, it can be distracting. Frankly, many of these flavors just do not play well with chocolate and should stay in their own neighborhoods. As I tasted them all, I found that several of the combinations just had no reason to exist. Just because you can make chocolate taste like locally grown rosemary does not mean you should.

Christopher Elbow likens itself as a chocolate artist. Unfortunately, like many artists, they get enamored with their materials and talents and forget their audience. So, rather than creating universally revered masterpieces, their work is rather masturbatory.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I'm always a little wary of going into stores where there are no other customers- I hate having the salespeople track my every move through the store and I hate feeling that I need to buy something in order to justify my presence.  I kept avoiding going into Christopher Elbow for that very reason- the space is very wide-open and I couldn't hide behind a display anywhere while I browsed their wares.  So I've got issues, but I finally decided to go in because I just couldn't resist the lure of their chocolates anymore.

Like a lot of the artisanal, high-end chocolate stores through San Francisco, all their chocolates are displayed on a pristine white table behind glass, like little pieces of edible art.  I liked that they have samples- in this case, I think it was the Venezuelan spice.  They were generous in their sample too- half a truffle, rather than a measly quarter.  That allowed you to get a nice mouthful of chocolate and to get a great sense of the actual taste and texture.  I've never particularly liked spice in my chocolate, but this truffle wasn't bad- there was a low level of heat at the back of the throat once you finished the chocolate but it wasn't too intense.  After that taste, I decided I'd try some of their other chcoolates.  The first chocolates that caught my eye were the fresh lime, which sounded interesting, and the yuzu, which sounded even more interesting.  I decided to go with the yuzu and also the Hawaiian macadamia with sea salt, which the salesperson said was the staff favorite.  Both were amazing!  I really wished I had got more, but at $2 a pop, I couldn't afford to try each and every last one.

I also saw that they have a dark chocolate drinking menu as I was paying for my chocolates.  It was too warm an afternoon to indulge, but many of the items sounds really interesting.  Chinese 5 spice and chocolate?  Sounds a little odd, but the salesperson assured me that it was actually good.  It looks like I'll have to make another trip back to Christopher Elbow and try their drinking chocolates when the weather cools a bit!
author: Angela H.

description: Elbow gets an extra star.  I have been back a couple more times.  Maybe they read my review (or maybe not), but the hot chocolates don't seem to burn my throat the way they did before.  That makes me happy because Elbow is walking distance from me and Bittersweet is not.  I also discovered that I really like Elbow's caramels, like the passion fruit and lavender ones.  I stay away from any ganache type of chocolate though...still too sour for my taste.
author: Kandi K.

description: I love the hot chocolate.  My favorite is the 85% dark.  It makes every hot chocolate I've had before pale in comparison.  The others are a bit too sweet for my taste, but my companions have enjoyed them.  It's worth a detour and/or an inclusion in a gastronomic tour of San Francisco.
author: Fabienne B.

description: Christopher Elbow was on our Hayes Valley Tour, and we're so happy it was! Although we can only afford a couple pieces at time, it is definitely worth going there. Not only does it look like a piece of art, it melts in your mouth and tastes heavenly. Great place to end your night after dinner.
author: shesaid t.

description:
4.25 stars.

Ordered the Chinese 5-spice hot chocolate with whipped cream.  Very chocolate-y and...5-spicy!  It was good, definitely unique.

 Cool place to drop by for some chocolate (they have a unique selection of chocolates) and just lounge around and read magazines.
author: Junkfoodie Q.

description: YUM! My friend and I agreed that from the outside, this place looks like an art gallery or something - very modern and chic, which is probably why a bumpkin like me had never walked inside. But another friend mentioned it to me and I wandered inside after lunch in Hayes Valley. Truly, it's Willy Wonka for grown ups. The chocolates are beautiful simply to LOOK at, let alone taste....hand painted morsels of deliciousness. I oohed and aaahed so many times I'm sure the chic guys behind the counter thought I was a total window shopper, but to my credit I bought two two-piece boxes (fleur de sel caramel, morello cherry, bananas foster and a plain dark chocolate piece) for me and a friend. Everything was dynamite and well worth the premium price. I also bought a dark chocolate peppermint bar that is currently burning a hole through its wrapper, I want to eat it so badly. Can't wait to go back!
author: Beth T.

description: Here's another place that seems to think that chocolate and salt go together. In fact, their dark chocolate patties would be 5 stars were it not for the salt. I had to give them up because I'd be loving the pattie and then hit the salt.
author: Charles B.

description: Lovely store.  Nice chocolates.  Very expensive.  As in... I bought a 9 piece box and one turtle and it was $23.  The spicy ones were great; I have an affinity for chocolate and chilis.  But it's hard to enjoy something when I know each bite is $2.  Like enjoying a massage when every minute is $3 and the therapist is 4 minutes late.  So, in short, good place, pretty, but not exceptional as these things go.  I prefer the funky little Five Star Truffles place on Divisidero, although it's an entirely different animal, for my own consumption.  This is a place for high powered attorney Christmas gifts, not a place to stop by to pick up a treat.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Oh my sweet heavenly Jesus! This is the most fantastic chocolate I have ever put in my mouth. Okay, so first of all, it's beautiful. I almost hated eating it. Almost. But I did. And it was absolutely fantastic. Try it! I would suggest giving this as a gift to those friends and family members of yours who already have everything. Like your granny. She'd love them! Make sure there's no wine or vodka in them though. Wouldn't want granny getting tipsy :)
author: Rebecca J.

description: Wow, I was blown away by the Blue Bottle Coffee chocolate.  I'm not even a fan of coffee but I loved the chocolate.  This is one serious piece of chocolate for $3 a piece, dare I say better than the cup of joe itself..so good!
author: Peachie Y.

description: I was skeptical of a $2 one inch piece of chocolate.  But, it's pretty amazing.  Bananas Foster really tastes like Bananas Foster.  Like the meal gum in Charlie and The Chocolate Factory.  Er, if that were real.
author: K W.

description: $5 for 2 chocolates?  Yes.  Worth it?  Maybe.  The Fleur de Sel  turtle was worth $3, but the coconut truffle was not worth $2.  I like the coconut truffles from 5 Star on Divis better than these, and I could get 4 truffles there for the same amount of moolah.
author: robyn s.

description: Very pretty chocolates.  They look like little gems!  What flavors do they contain?  Who knows, just eat it.  The few that I had were pretty good.  I was actually expecting something more.  The chocolate is surprisingly light on the palette.  It's not so heavy like a truffle or typical See's candie.  I intend to do more investigation later on...
author: Michael H.

description: What a surprise to see this huge chocolatier pop up in a former furniture store in Hayes Valley.  It's a beautiful space and the chocolates are amazing little gems.  We had dessert here after dinner in the neighborhood and found it immensely satisfying.  The Fleur de Sal is a must have, where our other picks (spicy caramel, banana curry, morello cherry) were all good -- and in some cases, exciting -- but not things we'll repeat soon either.   Too bad it's not open after performances, because we'd have stopped in then for a hot chocolate.
author: Paul H.

description: Last month I moved here from Kansas City, the home of CE Chocolates; I was thoroughly excited to find I would not have to be without them here in San Francisco.  Not only are the chocolates beautiful, the patterns changing with the seasons, they have unique tastes.  I recommend all of them, but my favorites are the lavender caramel and the rosemary caramel.  In addition, the drinking chocolate is dense and to die for.  This is a great place to go for a cozy afternoon with friends.
author: Elli F.

description: Wow. Chocolate finally gets some respect. A quick glance at this place and you'll mistake it for a jewelry shop. The staff treat their merchandise like it, too. We bought a nine-piece box of chocolates and we watched this guy select each piece, place them on a metal tray and then fit each one in its own paper cup before carefully placing it in a luxurious white box, then wrapping it all up in a wide, chocolatey-brown ribbon. Pricey, yes, but these ain't no Pot of Golds, dude.
author: Trevor J.

description: I can't believe I haven't yelped this place.  My sister (Mel P.) beat me to it and I brought her here.  As she already mentioned, the Liquid Chocolates (LC) are divine.  They're extremely rich and very flavorful.  They should be sipped but I have a tendency to gulped the damn thing down!  The first time I went, I had the Peppermint LC.  This time around, I had the Ginger LC!  You really can taste the flavors and the staff is pretty laid back and sweet.  The chocolates are pricey but the flavors are unforgettable.  It's the perfect gift for yourself or a loved one.  If you stick around, you can see the cars zoom by and the people walking up and down Gough street!  Such a great place!  If you love chocolate, please go to Christopher Elbow!!!!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
had to put my two cents in... beautiful, handmade chocolates that are scrumptious... a beautiful friend of mine bought me a small box for my birthday... 

when i came home, i kind of forgot about the box... a week later, the chocolates looked and tasted as if they had just came from the store!

definitely a great idea for gifts...

minus one star for the fact that they don't make the chocolate on site...
author: Jana A.

description: We give 5 stars because the chocolates are to die for, but Mabel's chocolate mocha is so rich and chocolatey I feel like I've gone to heaven. Mabel is so welcoming and gracious I would come back just because I know she truly enjoys her job and has fun serving others.
author: Emily W.

description: High End Chocolate with an Ultra Modern twist.  Great place to come and grab a cup of hot chocolate, twisted Coffee concoctions, and chocolate. I wouldn't consider this a great place to lounge around at but, more of a place everyone should experience for it's unthinkable cocao creativity.
author: Marco M.

description: I saw these on Food Network and was enticed by the Banana's Foster. Definintely upscale chocolates but the selection is insane. The Rosemary & Carmel chocolate is so frieken good! This is totally something you should treat yourself to.
author: Dena D.

description: YUM! My favorite, hands down, is the caramel made with passion fruit. I dont find the chocolates too overwhelming and they def. have unique tastes.
author: shadi m.

description:
This chic modern confection store displays it's chocolates like the jewels they are.  Arranged behind glass cabinets are truffles swirled with blue, green, orange, red, nearly all the colors of the rainbow, and also the more traditional natural chocolate color.  There are amazing exotic flavors like Yuzu, Rosemary Caramel, Lavender, and Fleur de Sel Caramel.  There are also Hazelnut and Peanut Butter Chocolate Patties.  The store has preboxed chocolates and the staff will box up your selection for you if you want to choose yourself.  The chocolates are a little pricey, you get 2 for 5$, 4 for 10$, 16 for 32$ and larger size boxes are available.  They also have the option of gift certificates.
It's nice to come in and sit down to enjoy a few candies and maybe a hot chocolate.  They have a great selection for the hot chocolate drinks also.  I like a cup of the old fashioned rich cocoa or a mocha, but there are also flavors like passionfruit, praline, and Chinese 5 spice hot chocolate.
The sitting area is fun.  There's a nice comfortable banquette with marble rests for your drinks and light up stools for extra seating.  There are large plate glass windows for people watching while you indulge.  There's also also a rack of local papers and magazines to read.
The staff is friendly and knowledgable.  They graciously offer glasses of water, because they know how chocolate will dry you out.
author: Michael D.

description: Living amid a sort of Bermuda Triangle of treat options (Miette, Blue Bottle Coffee being two other notable points within a block), I've been slow to enter Christoper Elbow Chocolates. However, holiday shopping and winter cold conspired to make me enter this sleek-lined business on the corner of Hayes St. & Gough twice in the past week. The chocolates are as beautiful as they are sumptuous, arranged like jewels in their boxes, and the hot chocolate.....ahem. Thankfully, the helpful barista/chocolate brewers can froth up your taste of rich goodness "European Style," that is with water instead of whole milk, to lesson the indulgence a tad, and spice it according to how much heat you can take. I'm a fan of both the Venezuelan Spice and a Masala-enhanced curried coco made with coconut milk alike.
author: Deborah C.

description: I am no chocolate connoisseur, but I know when I like the stuff, and let me tell you, these chocolates are DAMN GOOD.  Especially loved the rosemary caramel.  Rosemary in desserts is a new obsession in mine, especially if caramel is involved.  The lime was really interesting as well - a great tart bite to contrast the deep richness of the dark chocolate.  Also fun is that it's open late, so you can stop in for a late-night hot chocolate (which I didn't try, but I'm sure are amazing).  As I'm sure you guessed, these beautiful little delicacies don't come cheap, but they are their own reward.  (And they usually have samples on the counter!)
author: Rachel B.

description: Yah, the place is pricey like some complain about but I think its worth it. Especially the strawberry balsamic, YUM!
author: Jerry S.

description: OMG! I love this place! I'm going to get straight to it and tell you that  I had the cocoa noir a drinking chocolate...yum! It's creamy, velvety and rich! Sooooo good! It hits the spot and you want to just lick the whole cup after you are done because you don't want to waste any of the chocolatety goodness! I didn't get the chance to try any of the beautiful chocolates...too nice to eat...it looks more like art then chocolate...but next time I will try some! The staff are nice...and while you sip your chocolate drink there is a little area where you can sit and talk and people watch! What else can you ask for? Good stuff....
author: Mel P.

description:
Wow, we must have ordered the wrong stuff. 

I was on a hunt to try out these three bakeries in Hayes Valley I had read about in the SF Chronicle, and stumbled upon this artisanal chocolate shop. I, having a sweet tooth the size of the Pacific Ocean, absolutely had to try it. Luckily, I have very obliging parents. The chocolates were stunning. I took a picture just so I could remember just how gorgeous they were. When we tried them, however, I was pretty much the only one who enjoyed them. I tried the passionfruit caramel, the tahitian vanilla chocolate, the key lime truffle, and the champagne truffle. They were really good, but nothing outstanding. I would go back, but I'm not raving about them. I would pretty much rate this a 3.5.
author: Liv K.

description: wow. fancy pants chocolate heaven. very rarely do i feel like i get what i paid for, but here i'll happily turn over my hardearned cash. $2 per small chocolate piece, $3 for larger patties (peanut butter + hazelnut), $5 for cup of hot chocolate that blows the socks off of any other cup of hot choc you've had before. drink flavors include: extra dark, venezuelan spice, mocha, and lots of other stuff i don't remember. $7 for a choc bar, $16 for a tin of powdered choc to make your own choc drinks at home. surprisingly, the place doesn't smell at all like chocolate. there's a small seating area around the corner from the cash register where you can sip your drink + watch the parade of cars down gough.
author: Zoe L.

description: So if you want a hot chocolate this is your place.  Try the hazelnut blend it tastes like a box of Belgian chocolates is melting in your mouth.  Bananas foster chocolates are delish.   I have a friend that swears by the rosemary chocolates:  rosemary makes a fine christmas tree but I don't  eat it in anything.  If I were to bend the rules though I might start with one of Elbow's chocolates.
author: Ona E.

description: if you want a very very good hot chocolate and around the area, definitely this is the place to go.  Thick and rich chocolate with variety of favor; spice, hazelnut, lime, chily and others.
author: James L.

description: Chocolate craving?  If so, this is the place to go for your hankering.  The 'Russian Tea' chocolate (A dark chocolate ganache infused with black teas and scents of citrus, bergamot and spices) was delicious!  As well as the Champagne and Grappa Truffle-very rich.  They also have a chocolate with Pop-Rocks-very interesting.  And if you craving goes further, why not indulge in some drinking chocolate?  The 'Peanut Butter' drink is such a treat in itself and tastes like a peanut butter cup!  Also, the 'Curry' is nice too-half coconut milk & regular milk with a little spice make this a unique spin on a chocolate drink.
author: Steven K.

description: Gotta love this place. Their chocolate is good, but that isnt what makes me stop there often. I am there most often because of their hot chocolate. Its different. They do all sorts of cool things with it. Adding different flavors (like coconut milk and cayenne). This is my type of place. Invention and creativity run rampant with their beverageables.
author: H B.

description: ab fab chocolates!!!
author: deCabbit

description:
Christopher Elbow had me drooling for some of their Hot Chocolate. This is a well decorated place with superb customer service. While walking by, I instantly noticed something was different on that corner. It is so cool that some people may be afraid to go inside. Hot Chocolate is $4.50 and you will receive it casually in a paper cup. For me, having chocolate, dark or otherwise, makes me have to consider the saturated fat content and while I can splurge sometimes, I still like to have my non fat milk option. I might be anal about it but oh well, that is what aging does to ya... Nevertheless, I like this place, so for most of you ...give it a try and chill out in the cool lounge area sipping a rich cup of hot chocolate... 
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/03/17/christopher-elbow-exquisite-chocolate-lounge/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: I was really excited to see this place open, given that it is around the corner from my kids' school.  Sadly, it is WAY too expensive for what it is.  Basically, $2 per piece. 1" square, at the most.  Now, I readily acknowledge that this town is expensive.  And trust me, I pay for good chocolate - but $2 per piece is a bit ridiculous.  I'd rather shop at Miette (around the corner with an excellent range of chocolates and other candies) or Fog City News (downtown, also pricey but actually worth it so much more).   *sigh*  oh well.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Hot chocolate for $4.50 I can understand as it rich and creamy, but serving it in a paper cup, come on!  Chocolate's were just ok, no bourbon flavor in the bourbon chocolate.  The chocolates look amazing, but fell short on taste for me.  Nice looking shop, total hipster vibe inside, so if you think you look cool try out some mediocre chocolates.
author: Mickey D.

description: Oooooh I love chocolate. And I especially love wacky chocolate creations, which there certainly not a shortage of at Christopher Elbow. This trendy new chocolate bar fits perfectly into the Hayes Valley culture- where particularly well crafted and expensive food seems to rule.  The space is quite large, for a chocolate bar, in addition to the room with a huge counter holding the myriad chocolate gems, there is a lounge area where you can sit and sip their specialty hot chocolates. It is a given that I will come back to sample the hot chocolates, but for the time being, I am can only review the chocolates which were actually given out as samples for free! Russian tea and the Ecuador were among the sampling varieties. Not only did they look gorgeous (finely painted designs decorated these beauties) but the taste was exotic and sophisticated. I didn't actually purchase anything here, but flavors I will try in the future include the passionfruit, lime, Vietnamese cinnamon, and Venezuelen spice (with chili). Yes, I am in love with this place, and it is probably a good thing that I don't live nearby, otherwise I would be here every day.
author: Kate A.

description: i stumbled upon this place today while shopping in hayes.  the store is brand new and very clean and beautiful.  i bought a box of 4 chocs, and i chose:  strawberry caramel w/ balsamic vinegar, caramel w/ fleur de sel, a choc macadamia crunch, and a venezuelan spice.  these chocolates are too beautiful for words.  i haven't even tasted them yet, b/c they are too pretty to eat!
author: Helen T.

description: One of my all times favorites and a stop in San Fran. I prettyy much like all of their chocolates, but the standout is the rosemary caramel, which is almost as good as Christopher Michaels in Newport beach, down south. I have always order my chocolates via their online store, but stopped by their San Fran shop and picked up some Chocolates & liquid chocolate. I do have one complaint though. Their hot chocolate was not warn enough and was kind of gritty. The hot chocolate aside, I really enjoy these chocolates.
author: john s.

description: chocolate so pretty you won't want to eat them...well, you'll get over it. gorgeous pieces with delicious ingredients in a very sleek store. decadent.
author: Angela N.

description: Finally got the chance to stop in and what a treat! The prices are a bit high, but well worth it. Not only will it be hard to find this type of selection elsewhere, but what other chocolate store serves up espresso and has an area to lounge? Okay, maybe there is another and I don't know about it. But if there is another, I doubt it's gonna be cheaper, most chocolate stores are the size of the counter and then you are enjoying your chocolate on the street or have to wait to get home.
author: Lex m.

description:
i love this place!  perfect for a little after dinner treat.  the fleur de sel turtles are amazing and totally worth $3.  pretty much everything i have tried has been great.  

someone mentioned that they should give free samples.  everytime i am in there during the week they do, but it never seems to be of their best (in my opinion) flavours.  

my only small little tiny complaint is that they should perhaps stay open later than 10pm on weekends.  11pm would be perfect to catch the after dinner crowd.  i have been there at 10 several times on a saturday and lots of people were trying to get in for their candy fix!
author: n. h.

description: very unique flavors combinations. C.E. gets only three stars because the products they sell are made in Kansas City. What up with that??
author: Jeff B.

description: liquid chocolates are delicious. fantastic space - clean, hip. minimalist and decadent.
author: A K.
